Text: There are too many targets - you will not miss!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: They’re everywhere!!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: A narrow path negates superior numbers. Stay focused!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re almost there! That’s the last one! Hurry!
[Kratos cut down the last “muscle.” Everything begins to crumble.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy!
[They fall from a huge height. Kratos is grouped in the fall, and the impact is mostly on him.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Are you injured?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m fine. Wow… it’s beautiful… The light… it’s making the whole temple reappear. It’s the source of all of it. Wait - it’s… it’s singing. I hear… I hear her. I told you I heard her! do you think she’s in there?
[He tries to touch the light.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ahh! Aah… That really hurt. Felt like my hand was on fire…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stay here.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But I want to go --

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stay. Here.
[He’s handing over his axe to Atreus.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Only use it as a last resort.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You’re given me your axe?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I am letting you hold my axe. It is not a gift.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Still…
[Not without effort, Kratos enters the pillar of light. He gets into the black and white world like in God of War III.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is this-?
[He hears singing. A bag of his wife’s ashes flies away.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Faye?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You have to come back. You left me here alone.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: …alone with him. He always leaves. He’s never here. He doesn’t want me and never will. I don’t know him and he doesn’t know me. Doesn’t seem to want to. I’m strong. I’m smart. I am not what he thinks I am. I know better. He doesn’t talk to me. Doesn’t teach me. It should have been him. Do you hear me? Him… not you. Except… I don’t mean that. You know I love him. I just wish he was better. I know he can be. So if he tries… I’ll try. But if he doesn’t… please come back. I know you are out there somewhere.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Faye…
[Someone pulls him out…]
[Apparently it was Atreus who pulled him out.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: NO!!!… NO! What have you done? Why did you do that?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I saved you! You were trapped in there. I waited and I waited but you wouldn’t come out… So I pulled you out!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I was gone only…
[He sees PILES of dead enemies. Atreus takes his knife out of one of them and cleans it.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: moments…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: NO. You’ve been gone a long,  long time! I didn’t know what to do. You left me here. AGAIN. Why don’t you care?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I… That’s impossible.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We should go before they come back. I hope you got what you needed.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look! There’s our exit, but there’s no light to make a bridge. We’re trapped. And the witch’s bowstring as useless.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy… your bow. Hold it out.
[He charges the bowstring with his Bifröst.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: On my mark, loose your arrow into the stone.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It worked…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We can now make our way back. Come…
[Kratos picks up the crystal and looks for a place to put it.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You gonna carry that everywhere?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I just might.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What does this mean? Remember the shape.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah, I know…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Go ahead.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Greatest man nor tallest tree / Begins as any more than me.” Yeah - it’s “seed.” Stupid riddles… So it’s a door after all.

[Kratos uses his powerful muscles to open the door. The room is filling with Light Elves, but it is not entirely clear whether they are alive or just spirits. Atreus smiles joyfully. Kratos walks to Sindri.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You boys look like you are nearing up for quite the journey. There’s an abandoned temple in Midgard of that fellow Dwarf converted to his personal storeroom. Packed it with all sorts of treasures he collected and during his travels throughout the realms.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Throughout the realms? Which ones did he go to? What did he collect?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Fafnir was a… shall we say, “aggressive” collector of magical artifacts. The more he acquired, the more he desired. Is there was no realm too dangerous, no relic too hazardous. He once ventured deep into Niflheim for a whetstone, of all things! Huh. I bet that was quite the whetstone…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Does this story have a point?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Yes it does! I just happen to have an entry stone to Fafnir’s Storeroom! You might find something useful in there.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Neat! Thanks, Sindri!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You’re very welcome! Oh, and… if you find that whetstone… well… It sure would be nice of you to bring it to me!
[They’re going to the pier.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Great. The one with the horns is back. What does he want now? I hate that guy.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He will be back.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh no… the boat isn’t here - it’s still back out of the other side of the lake.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then we go back the way we came. The lift.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re really gonna go back down here again?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do you see any other way?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then?
[After they descend to the lower tier, the upper shutters close.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Great. Now I can barely see.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There is light. Make do.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Finally. We can use of the same sand bowl that brought us down the first time. I want to get out of here.
[Kratos is being attacked by the same horny elf. His name is Svartáljoffur (Black Suit?). Kratos beats him to death. Before he dies, a horny elf says something in his language.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No. It can’t be.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What did it say?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That we made a “grave mistake.” Did we help the wrong side?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I-

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Let me guess… you’re going to be smug and say you told me we shouldn’t get involved.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That is enough!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Can we go now?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do you remember the answer?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah yeah.
[He draw the symbol in the sand bowl.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Boy… read this. Boy… what’s that say?” Only time you want to talk to me is when you need something.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do you want to tell me something?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I said the only time you care to talk to me is when you need me to translate for you. If Mom was here-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If your mother was still alive, we would not be here at all. Atreus -

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Forget it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Fine.
[They get to the boat and continue their Journey.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So… Was she in the light?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Who.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You know.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. She was not there.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Not like you would even care if she was…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Mind your tongue, boy!  Until our journey is over, one of us must remain focused. Do not mistake my silence for lack of grief! Mourn how you wish, leave me to my own.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m sorry. I didn’t realise…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No… Why would you? You do not know my ways. I know it has not been easy. In the light… I felt only moments pass. If that is of some comfort to you.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s… good to know. Really. So… Should we go back to Midgard? Face the Black Breath? Or do you think there is more to see in this realm? Father? You ever know anyone else who heard voices?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I knew desperate men at sea who, when our supplies run dry, would quench their thirst by drinking seawater. They swore the sirens - evil creatures singing to them from nearby islands - were in fact their wives and daughters, calling them home. They endangered of the crew, steering us towards the reefs.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How did you fix them?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We threw them overboard.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh. Well, good thing I didn’t drink any seewater, right…?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes it is.
[They’re docking near some forest.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You’re back! I see you’ve been busy.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How observant.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: I am known for my attention to detail. Be careful where you’re going. There’s nobody nice out here anymore since all of the people left. I mean, I hate to generalise, but, umm, mostly if they just try to kill you.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Good tip. Father… I have a confession to make. All of those who voices in my head… well, this wasn’t the first time. Back when we met Brok… She warned me about something hiding in the trees. That’s why she didn’t want to cross.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She told you?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well… I could just feel what she was feeling… what is she was afraid of.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Mmm. It happens again you tell me. Understand?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I promise.
[They’re going back to the bridge between the worlds.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s crazy to think that all of the realms exist in the same space, one on top of the another. It’s like this room lets us travel without moving!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Brok! We just came back from another realm and we met your brother. Wait - not in that order.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Did you let seed-sop put hand to your blade? Do you do know he lost his talent, right? Just up and left him one day- tried taking me down with him. Did he botch up our girl?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Quite the opposite…
[He pulls out his axe and puts it on the table in front of Brok. He examines it.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: Hm… well, even a blind pig farts up a truffle now and again. But do you know what really counts? Consistency. And I got that comin’ outta ALLA my parts.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What did you do?

Speaker: Brok
Text: It’s better. Good. Now when you are done gawkin’, I got a favor to ask.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is it, dwarf?

Speaker: Brok
Text: There’s this Alchemist, Andvari, been workin’ outta the Völunder Mines. Haven’t heard from him in mebbe, oh I dunno… a hundred winters or so? Probably dead, but uh, mebbe you can find him. He’s Dwarven like me. Wears a fancy green ring. Owes me a favor. You’ll look?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If is it on our path…

Speaker: Brok
Text: Oh I see how it is. Not somethin’ fer nuthin’ type, are you? Fine! If ya find Andvari, I’ll make him whip ya up something special.This entry stone here oughtta get you inside those mines. I need that Alchemist for something I’m stewing up for you.If’n you’re smart, you’ll find him.
[Kratos going outside.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do you remember the way back to the Black Breath?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Of course. We need to walk across the bridge to the Vanaheim tower. Are we going to the Black Breath? Or exploring? Your choice.
[They’re getting on the boat and sailing on Lake of Nine.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Did you see something out there? That tower…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I see no tower.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Maybe I’m seeing things… I wish we could have gone on a trip like this with Mother. She could fight, couldn’t she?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. She fought… beautifully.
[They come to the mines. Brok meets them at the entrance.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: You scare up that Alchemist what needed finding? What realm you gents shakin’ off? Lemme guess… Alfheim?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How’d you guess?

Speaker: Brok
Text: I’d know that smell anywhere. Used to spend my fair share of time there but, uh, I ain’t allowed anymore on account of the, uh, incident.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What happened?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Welllll, ain’t too sure your daddy’s gonna like me talking about it on account of all the swearin’ and stealin’ and fuckin’ involved.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What?!?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Don’t judge me- you’re the one came in all reekin’ of Elf! Stirs up a man’s memories. Go on now- I got things that ain’t gonna hammer themselves…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What does it say?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Uh… these runes read ‘Death inside’. So… Brok and his friend was Dwarven like him, wearing a green ring.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Look if you wish. I will be gathering resources for our journey.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You don’t want to help him?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why not?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Because I do not run errands for dwarves.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s a Soul Eater! If that kills us, that’s it. NO VaIhaIIa. No Hel. No afterlife. Ever!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It does not attack.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh. Mom made them sound more dangerous than that.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then do not drop your guard. Come.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There’s the ring! On that severed hand! … attached to the Soul Eater. Well… we know what happened to Andvari now, we just go tell Brok. No need to fight it, right?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. We will fight it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But why?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Because you are frightened of it. Be strong, Atreus. Stay focused. and look for a week point.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes sir.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stay quiet. Make no sudden movement.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Here we go! Fire, incoming! We did it! I can’t believe it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Believe it. You are stronger than you know. Green ring. Dwarvish inscription…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The Alchemist. But where’s the rest of him?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Ashes, most likely.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The Soul Eater got him… I guess we should bring this back to Brok.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Read it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir! These runes were written fast. Its spells out: “Í Gimsteini” . Hmm… I don’t know that one.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We will ask the blue one.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So now you’re interested?

Speaker: Brok
Text: What’d you find?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Your Alchemist.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m sorry, Brok. The hand is all we could find, still wearing the ring. There was a Soul Eater inside, and, well… it must have buried away the rest of you.

Speaker: Brok
Text: S’pose you’ll still be wanting’ some compensation, huh?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Naturally.

Speaker: Brok
Text: “Naturally,” he says. Mjonefr uxi…
[He gave Kratos rare axe pommel.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: I’ll take a closer look at this here ring. Maybe Andvari left a bit a magic inside ’fore he croaked.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Dwarves can do that?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Sure. Dwarves and magic jewels is like flies and pig lips. Supple ones.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ew. I’m not as interested as I thought. Brok…

Speaker: Brok
Text: Fuck else you need…?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How come you brother’s got half your brand?

Speaker: Brok
Text: ’Cause I ain’t in a workin’ relationship with that foot-licker no more. I wasn’t about to let him use it without me and he likewise- only thing to do we split the brand, fifty-fifty down the middle. Guess that was the last thing we saw eye to eye on.
[Kratos and Atreus take the boat and sail away.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: SO! Know any good stories to pass at the time?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What kind of stories?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I don’t know… Mother always had stories. Weren’t you told any when you were a boy?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There was a man a new of long ago… His stories were brief, and purposeful.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Sounds… fun? Do you remember any?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hm… there was one that concerned a hare and a tortoise.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Like the Witch’s house?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Unlikely.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So what happens?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: They wager on a race between them. The hare is too confident of victory, and foolish while the tortoise is steady, and disciplined. The tortoise wins.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You… haven’t told a lot of stories, have you.
[On a small island, they kindle a brazier and kill several enemies.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is over.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Well fought, you too.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What is that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: A Spirit.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s talking to us!

Speaker: Spirit
Text: And it hears you as well! Don’t be shy now.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You’re… dead?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: You’re very perceptive! Take caution when lighting these Braziers. Seiðr and Hel-Walkers will swarm to the flames like moth. I assume we have you to thank for freeing us from a watery grave.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Us?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Other spirits. The Lake of Nine is full of ’em! Most are able to move on from this realm, but we “lucky” few are stuck here in Midgard until our affairs are in order. Perhaps you can help them as well?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We have no desire to help you, Spirit.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Ah, but you already have! I only wished to see the sky again. Farewell.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoah. He disappeared!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come. Let us not be distracted.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So, I guess we should keep an eye out for other Spirits.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What did I say about distractions?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But it sounds like they needed help.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: They are Spirits, boy. Dead things. They have no needs. Only wants.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It feels wrong to ignore them.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You will get over these feelings.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mom would have wanted to help them…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What was that, boy?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nothing!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I thought as much.
[They continue their journey to Black Breath.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Just make sure you watch each other’s backs in the storeroom. Wouldn’t want to lose my loyal customers!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father? Do you… do you think I could care her now?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But I…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I said no.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay. So who do you think carved the face in the mountain?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You would know better than I.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Thanks.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now watch your step. Carelessness will only delay us.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Right. Will there’s the Black Breath that again. What do we do now?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We see if the witch was right.
[He uses Belfröst to cut through Black Breath.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s working! She was right!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come. Let us finish this.
[Kratos eliminate the Black Breath. THE LIGHT OF ALFHEIM COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The path ahead, it’s blocked.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: When we climb.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You know… Mother said the Giants used to visit the Midgard mountains before they disappeared.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Disappeared?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah. I guess they just up and left one day. No one knows why.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Perhaps they returned to their home.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Jötunheim? Maybe. I wonder if the face in the mountain was a tribute to some important Giant? The mouth… we made it!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: More Black Breath.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That emblem - it matched the one on the floor to Jötunheim in Týr’s temple. The Giants did come here! Is that… a deer? I don’t remember stories of a giant with a deer head. Wonder who he is? No way across, but there’s a sand bowl.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What does it say?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “No yoked beast, nor fearful thrall / Nor rooted tree doth know my call."

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hm.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can almost make it out… Runes! I can read it now!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Is it the answer?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Freedom"… sure, that works!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Go ahead.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Sure. Frelsa. What’s it doing? Oh! Thought maybe there’d be a bridge.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Rrrn. Your Giants mean to test us further.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There’s a crystal in that torch holder: Should I light it? That helps, right? Guess we have to down to go up?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: These passages seem too small for Giants.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: (giggles]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why do you laugh?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh… you’re serious.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I am always serious.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I forget… Mom always said you never took an interest in history. Giants are just a race, like Elves and Huldrafolk. It doesn’t mean that they’re big.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What of the World Serpent?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay, in that case, giant also means big. But there’s only one of him. Uhh… this is a lot of bodies.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Tell me what you see.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well… they look like men, not Giants.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Correct. Thiefs seeking treasure. See the traps?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh yeah. Lucky for us and they set ’em all off.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Be grateful these stay dead.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The statue! We made it across!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Read it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes sir. Ohhh… this is Duraþrór, one of the four stags of the World Tree. He’s supposed to watch the entrance to Jötunheim while the giants sleep. Think he’s still there?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I do not know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow. “The highest peak in the realms.” Think Mom knew this was the Giant’s mountain?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. Her request has been more… complicated, than she could have foreseen.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It means “terror". What’s that? Weird. There’s a candle all tangled up with string and some sort of animal hide. Some kind of lantern? No wick though.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That is of no use to us. That Bifröst lights our way.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hey, who do you think lit these torches? The dead don’t need light.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Eyes open.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa… what is all this? Where are we?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: A mine… and if this claw reaches the summit, our goal is near.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Alright. How do we use it? I think I see how this works… the Claw’s on the one side, and if we get this unstuck-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: BOY!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh no! I think the rope’s stuck under that rock.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That was careless.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes sir. Sorry, sir. It’s stuck. But maybe we can find a way up through there! After… you know… getting rid of those things. The machinery in here looks almost Dwarven, but the stonework… that’s definitely Jötun. You know, I think the Giants not only mined of the mountain, but actually lived here.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Read it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir! That’s funny…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How so?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: One hand wrote “Jötnar only” and another wrote “and also Dwarves.” Should we add to it?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.
[In the depths of the caves they meet an old friend…]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You had a way around the black breath all along?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Now don’t go thinkin’ I coulda gotten you past it, you big sack o’ meat. I got ways around most everything, especially up here. Time was my folk had the run o’ this joint. Improved the design of the Jötnar traps and built work-arounds ta boots. Why ya think they’re so devious? Oh, that reminds me- watch out for traps.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look! Another lantern!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Broken. Leave it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What could they be for? There’s something special about them. I can feel it. No way. You did it! I bet we can make the rope wheel work now. Might give us a way to the top!
[They are attacked by a troll named Járn Fótr (Iron Foot).]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Right behind you! I’m ready! Careful!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Back to do wheel.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ohh, I see that we’re doing… it fits! That’s perfect… That should hold it. Here we go. Do you think of this goes all the way up to the top?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We will see soon enough.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Something… feels strange up there. We’re heading into danger.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do not concern yourself with what might be. Focus on what is… and be vigilant.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes sir. Not over top… but we are closer. Wait! That one’s not broken! There’s a note… a Giant’s prayer. They’re asking ancestors to watch over them… to guide them home.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy-

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait! I think I know how it works…
[Atreus writes something on the lantern, sets it on fire and launches it into the air.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Watch. Wow…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What did you write?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I asked them to watch over mother. Do you think they’ll watch over us on our way to the top?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come, boy. It is a long way up.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Dwarfs must have carved these tunnels around Giant’s traps. Good thing too. Well… good for me anyway. Another mining lift! It may not be as long as we thought. That did it! Or not. Are we still too heavy? All right! We’re moving again. Hey, when we get to the summit, how far do you think we’ll be able to see? The lake? The World Serpent? Our house?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We will see when we get there. Until then, eyes open.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus?!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m fine. Just lost my balance for a moment. You know, for someone so strong your sure worry a lot.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It serves me well… and how I keep us alive.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I guess. Not a terribly fun way to live though. Sure are a lot of draugr around here! Draugr down! Alright!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How was that for “fun?"

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I get it. Is this where we get off?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. We are stuck.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I think part of the lift is stuck in that wall. Can you get it free? How much farther do we have to go?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I do not know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Think we’ll get attacked again?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Definitely.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh boy.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. Now, be ready.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Here we go! Shouldn’t we get moving? They could be back any moment. Think we’re safe now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It would seem.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father? After we scatter Mother’s ashes… What then? What comes next?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Nothing comes next. We go home.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s it? The adventure is over?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: For now. But we will have much to do. You were right earlier - on the boat after cutting down the last tree. You said it felt like something had changed. And it has, and our home is no longer safe. But it will be again. And we must continue your training.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay. We’re almost at the summit. Nothing’s going to stop us-
[A huge creature appears that looks like a dragon and belches lightning.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Calm yourself, boy! And stay behind me!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir!
[The fight with Hræzlyr begins.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Right behind you! Look out! Here he comes! Watch out! What are you doing?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Be ready! Hold on!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Phew… that was intense.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hold.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoah… what was that? That looks like a root of the Yggdrasil tree! Is that its sap?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Crystallized sap… and there is power inside.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Incredible! I can’t believe we fought a dragon! I was aiming for his eyes, but I kept losing my footing. Do you think this is their home? Did they move in after the Giants left? Or are they WHY the Giants left?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy. The air grows thin here. No more questions. Breathe.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh… yes… I see…

Speaker: Voice
Text: Ahh! Ahhh! Go away! Shoo! Shoo! Ahh! Help! Help!!!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Do you hear that? It sounds like something screaming.
[They go outside and see the dragon that attacks someone.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Wait, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s Sindri! Can you kill something that big?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If we can catch it off balance.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can distract him.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What are you doing?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We have to help him.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You break right. Find an angle. Wait for my mark.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Thank you. Hey ugly! Over here! You okay?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: For now!
[Kratos begins to fight the dragon. When the dragon understand he cannot defeat Kratos, he switches to Atreus.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy! Are you okay?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have a plan! Be ready to lower the crane on my mark!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But… I don’t know how this thing works!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I do not care! Be ready!
[Kratos fights with the dragon a little more.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: NOW!!
[Atreus shoots off the crane. Kratos uses it penetrate dragon’s skull.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Rrrrrgh!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow. We actually did it! And you-

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ahh… but-but-but-nobody’s killed a dragon for hundreds of years… not since the Grand Culling of the Wyrms! And unless I’m mistaken, you did all of that… for me!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You are mistaken. The dragon was simply in our path… nothing more.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You deny it all you want, but you saved me. And that… deserves compensation.
[He pulls a bunch of green arrows from his bag.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What are these?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Braided mistletoe arrows. Straighter than Heimdall and perfectly weighted.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh. Thanks?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh, okay… Hold on… uh… not that… um… you see my brother again?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah! He said you lost your talent.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh, and that I’m selfish , I’m sure. That I value a weapon’s look  over its purpose. That I am pretentious  and uptight. Fussy. I know what he thinks. But he can’t hurt me any- AH!!! Burn that.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I do not have time for this.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: No! No-no-no, wait-wait-wait… I have a better idea.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: I just need a tooth from that dragon. Watch where you grab tha… oh… never mind. So unclean. So, so unclean. Oh, the smell! Perfect, that should do. Ugh. Yeaaah… I’m not touching that. Just hold it out. Now run that along the string of your son’s bow. Just humor me.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus… your bow.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Two passes should do it. Gently now!
[Atreus gets Shock Arrows.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh sure, now you’re impressed. Oh… how do I explain this?I’ve added a new vibrating pattern to the bowstring’s fibers. Aiming it at that hardened world tree sap will vibrate it’s patterns to fracture point.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What’s… that mean?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh! Oh… I see you figured it out on your own then. Just… Never mind. I wasn’t just explaining the beautiful and complex artistry of my craft or anything… No, just… anything to help you. Yep.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Feels like it wasn’t that long ago we were hunting deer. Now we’re fought Dark Elves, and trolls, and ogres, and a dragon! I feel like we can beat anything now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We win because we are determined. Disciplined. Not because we feel ourselves superior.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Sure… I know… it’s just… it feels good to be strong. You know?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: …Yes. I know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Huh?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Ready yourself, boy. Look here. Another.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This one’s called Ymir. Mother tries to tell me this one, but I think I was too young. Are Giants coming out of his armpits? I think that might be Odin stabbing him. It’s getting colder - we must be near the top! Not long now, Mom.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look! The summit! We’re so close now…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Your quiver.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Strap broke when we fought in the dragon. It’s all right- I can hold it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stop. A broken quiver will slow you draw. Pain we endure, faulty weaponry we do not. This will do for now. Good?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Good.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Go. Steady, boy. Mind your footing.
[distant voices]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You hear those voices too, right?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. Be silent…

Speaker: Voice 1
Text: You know why we’re here. my last visit manage to loosen your tongue?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That sounds like the same man who came to our house. You said you killed him…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Shhh.

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: I see you brought company this time. Must be important if the sons of Thor deign to grace me with their presence. Tell me… you two still tripping over yourselves to impress daddy?

Speaker: Baldur
Text: The tattooed man. Tracks show he now travels with a child. Where would they go next?

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: Why would I know that?

Speaker: Son of Thor
Text: You’re the smartest man alive, aren’t you?

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: Smarter than all of the dead ones, too.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: You help me, I help you. Tell me where they are and I’ll talk to Odin-

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: Your father won’t let me go, Baldur, and he won’t let you kill me. You have nothing to offer me. Do take your questions, take your threats, take this two worthless wankers, and piss off.

Speaker: Son of Thor 2
Text: When no one’s looking… we’ll be back for your other eye.

Speaker: Son of Thor
Text: Don’t you forget… we’re everywhere.

Speaker: Son of Thor 2
Text: We really are, aren’t we?

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Shut up, you idiots. Let’s go.

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: Ahhh… the very topic of conversation… a tattooed man traveling with a child.
[They see a satyr fused with tree.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy, check their path and make sure we are alone.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But… we just saw them leave.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do as I say.

Speaker: Satyr
Text: He doesn’t know what you are…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: And I would keep it that way. Who are you?

Speaker: Satyr
Text: Me? I’m the greatest ambassador to the gods, the Giants, and all the creatures of the Nine Realms. I know every corner of these lands, every language spoken, every war waged, every deal struck. They call me… Mimir! -smartest man alive, and I have the answer to your every question.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why does the son of Odin hunt us?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Okay, there are a few gaps in my knowledge. But Odin’s had me imprisoned here for… 109 winters. I’m a clever lad, I can piece it together, I promise. Just… given time.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nobody there… just like I said.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The boy’s mother is dead. She wished her-

Speaker: Atreus
Text: She wanted us to spread her ashes on the highest peak of all the realms.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, then you’ve come to the wrong place, little brother. The highest peak in all the realms is not here in Midgard. It’s in Jötunheim, realm of the Giants.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That could not be what she meant…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Take a look… This is the last known bridge to Jötunheim in all the realms. See that mountain, looks like a Giant’s finger scraping the sky? That’s the highest peak in all the realms… Not here.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Can’t we just take that bridge? We have a Bifröst.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: When the Giants destroyed all the other bridges to the realm, they locked this one up with a secret rune. If it still exists, only a giant would know it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And all of them left Midgard a long time ago…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: True. But today the winds of fate have kicked up a strange vortex of coincidence. Fact is, there’s only one person alive who can get you where you need to go… and luckily for you, my schedule’s wide open.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re going to Jötunheim, right?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It’s your best and only move from a tactical standpoint. It’s the one place the man who cannot be killed won’t follow you.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What do we do?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: First, you need to cut off my head.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait, what?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Odin made sure that no weapon, not even Thor’s hammer, could free my body from these bounds. But fortunately, you don’t need my body. The trick is, we need to find someone who can reanimate my head, using the old magic.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Old magic… there is which of the woods, she knows the old ways.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: And she’ll help? She might do. Worth a try!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: But if she fails, you will be dead.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He tortures me, you know. Every day, brother. Odin himself sees to it personally, and believe me, there is no end to his creativity. Every. Single. Day. This… this isn’t living.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Very well.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can’t watch this.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Brother, in case you can’t resurrect me, there is something you need know. The boy… the longer you wait to tell him his true nature, the more damage you do. He will resent you, and you may lose him forever.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There is much about me I would not have him know.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye… so you value your privacy more than you son?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I’m going to cut your head now.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Fair enough.
[Kratos chopped off Mimir’s head with one mighty swing and takes it with him. INSIDE THE MOUNTAIN COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Jötunheim. We’re going to Jötunheim. We’re going to find the long-lost realm of the Giants. That’s… that’s-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Inconvenient.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah… that’s… just what I was going to say. So this is the bridge to Jötunheim? This looks like those weird doors we’ve seen. I guess Mimir will help us figure it all out… If we can bring him back to life.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do you remember the way to the Witch’s house?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes. The woods with the blood-red leaves south of the lake. I know just where to go. Hope she made it back from Alfheim and can bring Mimir back. He seemed nice, before you cut off his head.
[They enter the door between realms using for fast traveling.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look at these place… This must be a branch of the World Tree!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy! Stay on the path.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Right. Right, I know… I can’t believe it was Baldur that came to our house. The Aesir god, Baldur. And you fought him… and won!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: One of Odin’s sons - Thor’s brother. And now he’s hunting us with his nephews? Why is this happening?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If we can raise the head, you can ask him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay. You know… it’s silly, but I secretly hoped we could find a giant somewhere in that mountain. I guess they really did leave Midgard - except for the serpent. He may be in the last of his kind. Are you the last of your kind, too? Is that why you don’t like talk about -

Speaker: Kratos
Text: My kind?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I mean… your family? Before mother and I. Where you came from… a mother? A father?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now is not the time for that.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir.
[They enter the door leading to Brok’s workshop.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Brok! Brok…!! Brok!!!

Speaker: Brok
Text: WHAT?! I’m on the fuckin’ break. You don’t hear me screechin’ at you whenever you’re twiddling your short and curlies.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Leave him, boy.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Oh fer… you already soiled my solitude, so ya may as well join me.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We are not hungry.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Good. That’s not what I was offerin’.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Saw your brother again!

Speaker: Brok
Text: Congratulations. And I’m sure you let him go and roger my axe good and plenty again. Let’s see the damage…
[Kratos throws him his axe.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: Little canker-throat wouldn’t know proper weight and balance if it were dangling off his chut. He eating well enough?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I guess…

Speaker: Brok
Text: Good. All better. Know what the fuck else you want, huh? ’Times he gets so wrapped up in his work, Sindri hasn’t the sense to sip or sup. And if he does remember, good luck getting him to cook his own meat. Guess I got all the stomach in the family, along with the smarts.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You miss him.

Speaker: Brok
Text: What? That spit-fister? Whatta you know…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I just mean-

Speaker: Brok
Text: Hey, do you mind? Trying to concentrate here. Already on a break from my break…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hey! Where’s the beast of burden?

Speaker: Brok
Text: What do you mean? I ate her. Crapped bits of ’er out just a while ago.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What is wrong with you?

Speaker: Brok
Text: What? Her milk run dry.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: She was your friend!

Speaker: Brok
Text: Then she’ll be happy I’m so well fed. Shit-bricks, boy, you got a real sentimental streak, know that? Don’t get yourself confused out there. I’m gettin’ back to it…
[They exit the workshop.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy, what is the path back to the witch?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: First we need to find a boat.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do you remember the way back to the witch from here?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That way! Behind the big statue of Thor. So… what other stories have you got?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That was… a horse. The horse sought vengeance upon his enemy, a stag. But he could not kill the stag alone. The horse met a man, a hunter, and made a deal. He took the man’s bit and bridle, and allowed him to ride in a saddle on his back. Together, they killed the stag, and the horse tasted victory. But the hunter would not release the horse, and made a slave of him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So getting revenge cost him his freedom. Hope it was worth it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It was not.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The World Serpent’s even over here! I told you he’s big.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy, over here.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yessir. “Kveikja” (Ignite]

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I don’t believe it. Are you both… alive?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hello!

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I can’t remember the last time I saw something walk this islands that wasn’t dead or corrupted.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What do you mean?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: The Desolation, child. It plagues this land, growing more severe with every passing winter.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do you know it’s cause?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Not for certain, but I suspect the appearance of the World Serpent… along with the Great Flood that followed. Many were drowned, myself among them. The dead began to walk not long after.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Do you need anything from us?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy!

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I only wished to speak to someone again- a wish you just have granted.
[Kratos finds the last piece in Muspelheim cipher.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hey… this does want them decipher those Muspelheim runes - it also contains the travel rune. Should we go visit the Fire realm?
[Without answering anything Kratos lowers the boat into the water.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy. What did I tell you about offering help?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Don’t".

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Correct.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But can’t we just -

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This is not a debate. You must learn focus. Our journey need to be your only concern.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But what if they can help? That one seemed to know a little about the lake.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: And how does that help us with our goal?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We don’t know unless we ask! Want to try another story? Can’t be any worse then the last one.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Very well… There was a tale of a frog. His pond had dried up, so the frog and his son left to find a new home. They found a well. The son saw the water and made to jump in, but the father stopped him. He saw that the well was deep and once inside, they would not be able to escape if the water dried up again. Wisely, they moved on.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s it?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s really not a story. If the son jumped in, it would be a story.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: When he would be trapped, and starve while the father watched helplessly.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: See? That’s a story.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Treasures from all the different realms… Do you think Fafnir went to Alfheim too?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I do not know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Aren’t you curious? He sounds interesting.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We go to this storeroom to collect anything useful for our journey. Not to learn more about the dwarf.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Just make sure you watch each other’s backs in the storeroom. Wouldn’t want to lose my loyal customers!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Reavers.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Uh oh. They must’ve been got here first. Looks like the reavers made it inside. I hope they didn’t take all the treasure…
[Kratos clears room 1.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Just some stupid pots… and draugr. No magical treasure, and no whetstone.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Keep your expectations low, boy, and you will never be disappointed.
[Kratos clears room 2.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: They caught you off-guard.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I wasn’t expecting them!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Exactly.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Huh… there is nothing but poison in this one. And a stupid bird statue.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: AND useful resources, the main reason we are here, boy. However… many of these chests have been emptied.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Probably by the Reavers… I hope they didn’t take Sindri’s whetstone.
[Kratos clears room 3.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I have a good feeling about this next one. Maybe we’ll even find whetstone!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Remember what I told you about expectations, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Keep them low,” I remember. Still. Good feeling!  So much for my good feeling.
Action: (the room turns out to be empty)

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Mmm-hmm.
[Kratos clears room 4.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I was ready for them, this time.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I saw.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So I should keep my expectations low, but always expect an attack?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is a delicate balance. Expect the worst. Assume nothing. And always anticipate an attack.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Sure is a lot to remember. Wolves! Still no whetstone. And only one room left. I know I shouldn’t hope, but… do you think we’ll find it there?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.
[Kratos clears the last room.]

Speaker: Spirit
Text: So… back to piss on my corpse? You ungrateful little -- Eh? Who are you two?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re looking for a whetstone. Have you seen it?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Aye. There was one in this room. My son sharpened his dagger on it, right before stabbing me in the back.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Little bastard thought it was his turn to lead my crew. I was hard on him, sure, . Guess I shouldn’t be surprised. I did the same thing to my dad when I was his age.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He killed his own father?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Where is he now?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Ha! He may be a bastard, but he’s MY bastard. You’ll never get no help from me, fool.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: When his dagger will help.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Hey! That’s mine! HEY!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come boy, we are leaving.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why would he son betray him like that? Kill his own father? Over some treasure? It seems so greedy.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Remember what I told you, boy. Assume nothing.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well - sure, he didn’t seem like a great father. But…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You only know half the story.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I guess…
[They going back to Sindri.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You… didn’t happen to find that whetstone, perchance?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We found no whetstone. This dagger belongs to the Reaver who took it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: They took most of the good stuff.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh? Well… Here, take this. In exchange for the dagger. That dagger you brought me is quite interesting. An artist design, but the construction is sound. Where in the temple did you find this?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: In a Reaver’s back.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ugh… Uuuughhhh…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He mentioned he was part of a larger clan. Maybe they took the whetstone?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Quite possibly. I know I’ve seen of this design before…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So how come Brok’s blue and you’re not?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh, it’s fine - very good question actually. You see, my brother’s not as careful as I am - in fact, he prefers to work with metals using… his own bare hands. No gloves! Says it’s the only way he can “hear what it wants to be.” Touch enough raw silver and it changes your skin irreparably. (That means forever!) I wouldn’t bring it up to him though. You know how sensitive he can be.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I guess that makes sense. Sindri, why don’t you just make up with your brother already?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Me? Make up with him? Because his in obstinate pig-head, incapable of change. Because he says the most horrible things about me, just because he’s insecure about his own work - which, let me tell you, is sub-par. Because he blames me for - for the things that aren’t my fault!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Huh? Like what?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Would you pardon me please? I’d like to collect myself.
[Kratos and Atreus take the boat and sail away.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So… what other stories have you got?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There was a young man who was caught stealing and condemned to die. His mother came to visit his prison. She was a kind woman, who could only give love. But her son, the thief, met her with rage, and bit off her ear.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What! Why?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Because the boy had always been a thief. And his mother had taught him only love, and nothing of consequences. Had he been taught discipline instead, he might have lived longer.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Sure, but… her ear… that’s not right.
[They approach the island and destroy its inhabitants.]

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Ha! Well done, boys! Never thought I’d see a scrap like that again.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What do you want?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: To thank you! These dead Reavers drowned me many winters ago, and I’ve been itching to see ’em get theirs.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So you died after all the flooding?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Indeed. I came to the lake of nine to pillage Tyr’s Temple. But I underestimated the severity of the Desolation.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Have you seen other men? Living? A bearded one with tattoos?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Only the one standing in front of me! Thank you both for avenging my death. (disappears]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Useless.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, we can’t expect them ALL to know something useful. Maybe the next one will have more information.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Keep your expectations low, boy. Spirits are really useful.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How do they even exist?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: When you sever a man from his life, it is not always a clean cut.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So you’ve met other spirits?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. Many.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What were they like?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Annoying.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How about one more story?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: One more. There was the story of the mother crab, who scolded her son. She told him he should walk forward, in pride - not sideways as he always did.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But she’s a crab too! She should say, “sure, I’ll walk forward as soon as you show me how!”

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. She did say that. That was the story.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I got it.
[On the next island…]

Speaker: Spirit
Text: You! I must speak with you!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I came to this lake with a group of tradesmen, seeking refuge from the Desolation. But how could we know which was even worse at the Lake of Nine!?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We cannot undo your mistakes, Spirit.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I know that. But I fear for my captain and crew. I believe they are still under the water. Will you find them for me?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Is there anything you can offer us in return?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I… I have little to offer…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh… Well, I’m sure…

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Wait! I died wearing a valuable family heirloom. It’s yours, if you promise to find my crew.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Deal!

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You learning.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why don’t you or Mom even tell me about the Desolation?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I won’t speak for your mother… But it was never my concern. Nor should it be yours.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Doesn’t it concern us if everything around us is dying?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Our only concern is reaching Jötunheim.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Really? When why are we exploring all this islands?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The resources we find improve our equipment. If we stray from the path, it is only to prepare ourselves for the journey ahead.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can live with that if it means we keep exploring. And helping others. So… what other stories have you got?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There is a tale about a woodsman. He asked the trees of the forest for a branch to make a handle for his axe. Instead, the trees gave him a young sapling, so they could keep their limbs. The woodsman made his axe. And then he returned, and chopped down the oldest trees in the forest.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hm… just cause the trees are old doesn’t mean they’re smart… What happened here?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Shipwreck.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, yeah. I wonder why it crashed? You got any more “short and purposeful” stories for me?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Very well… There was once a scorpion who wished to travel to the other side of a river.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If you continue to interrupt, I will end the story.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay, okay.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The scorpion asked a frog for help. He told the frog that if he gave him a ride across the river on his back, he would be rewarded. The frog protested, fearing in the scorpion would sting him. The scorpion assured the frog that he would not sting him or they would both drown in the river. The frog agreed, but halfway across the river the scorpion stung him. The frog was mortally wounded and they both sunk to the bottom of the river and perished.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s sad. Why would the scorpion do that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He was a scorpion. It is his nature to do harm.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh… that’s just what Mom used to say about the gods.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You mother always spoke the truth. Enough stories.
[They sail into the house of the witch.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I know she’s really powerful, but you really think the witch can bring a hat back to life?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She seems competent in her craft. And we have nothing to lose.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: If she can’t bring it back to life, can we keep the head?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. But you may feed the fish.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay! I bet this’ll led out… “Turn back, Aesir.” Guess the gods aren’t welcome here.
[Atreus walks to a body of some warrior.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There he is! I hope he remembers us. How’s it going, Chaurli? Is your witch friends here?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is that name?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s what he told me it was - or what it sounded like in my head anyway. Chaurli!
[They enter the Witch’s hut.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father - she is here! It is so good to see you again! I knew you weren’t dead.
[The Witch hugs him.]

Speaker: Witch
Text: Hello…!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh… can you bring a head back to life?

Speaker: Witch
Text: I’m… not sure I understand what…  Wait… Where did you get those? The arrows… Give them to me. NOW.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: They were a gift…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do as she says, boy.

Speaker: Witch
Text: These arrows are dangerous… they’re wicked. You find any more, you destroy them. Understand? DO YOU UNDERSTAND? SAY IT!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I understand! If I see them, I’ll destroy them!

Speaker: Witch
Text: It’s all I ask. Forgive me. Please - take my arrows in their place. I have no need for them anymore. Now… what’s this about a head?
[Kratos pulls out Mimir’s head. The witch backs away in horror.]

Speaker: Witch
Text: Do you have any idea who this is? Did you kill him?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: At his request. He claimed you could revive him.

Speaker: Witch
Text: Me? Are you sure you heard him right?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Please?

Speaker: Witch
Text: Take him to the table. Heimili. It’s been a long time since I’ve practiced the Old magic. Hold him there - let’s have a look. Well, thankfully, his head hasn’t decayed much and his brain is still intact. Nice, clean cut. Cutting off his head of all people… I sure hope you know what you’re doing. Now hold his head under the water and don’t let go. I mean it. That’s enough.
[Mimir’s head coughs.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It worked!

Speaker: Witch
Text: Let me see him. Mimir… you there?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Yes…

Speaker: Witch
Text: Good.
[She spits in his face.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh… Hello, Freya. Been a long time! You look well.

Speaker: Freya
Text: What I did, I did for them. As far as I’m concerned, death suits you better.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’d bow if I could, your majesty. Forgive me - had I know the “witch of the woods” was Freya herself, I never would have suggested this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Freya? The goddess Freya?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You didn’t know either? Sorry.

Speaker: Freya
Text: When the word gets out of that Mimir is free, the wrath of Odin wouldn’t be far behind.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You are a god…

Speaker: Freya
Text: Leader of the Vanir once, yes… but no longer.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You did not think it important to tell me?

Speaker: Freya
Text: Are you really going to lecture me about that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We are leaving, boy. Now.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But-
[Kratos punches the door. They are leave the hut.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why did you do that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We cannot trust her.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Because she’s a god?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Have I taught you nothing, boy?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But she’s helped us a lot.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She lied.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Some people value their privacy. Best not to judge, brother.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: When I require you consel, head, I will ask.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Fair enough. Get me to Tyr’s temple in the Lake of the Nine, and I’ll get you to Jötunheim as promised.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We know the temple. What’s there?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Only the last living Giant in Midgard. Who better to tell us the way?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The world serpent? Wait- do you know how to talk to him?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Indeed. He speaks an obscure tongue, more ancient even than these mountains. None left in Midgard who speak it. Except, of course, for me.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You do?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It’s true. You wouldn’t know it to look at him but Jörmungandr is a sparkling conversationalist.
[They board the boat.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So, Mimir… why did Freya spit in your face?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No, speak of Baldur. He claims nothing harms him.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, Baldur is blessed with invulnerability to all threats, physical or magical.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The boasting of a god. Everyone has a weakness.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not him, I’m afraid. Baldur is blessed with invulnerability to all threats, physical or magical.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You just said that, Mimir.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Did I?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is the source of his power?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, as I recall… it involved… eh… a spell?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Parts of m’brain must still be coming back to life. Just need a moment to finish waking up.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hope he’s not broken… Mimir, we’re in the lake.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Perfect - dock us near the bridge!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir, you never did tell me why Freya spit in your face.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, she blames me in large measure for her present circumstances… and not totally without reason. It all goes back to the Long War between the Aesir and Vanir. Prior to that, wars for the Aesir were easily won - but the Vanir had proved their equal, and exacted devastating damage. Both sides suffered tremendous losses… and for many of us, quite frankly, war was simply no fun anymore, but a rather senseless waste of precious life. Wouldn’t you agree, brother?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Ngr.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Precisely. Enough was enough, and at last, Odin’s most brilliant advisor became determined to find a more enlightened path. He said about the broker of peace between the Gods. It took some convincing but ultimately Odin was persuaded to marry his deadliest enemy - a certain Vanir goddess, legendary not only for her fertile beauty but her genius at the very Vanir magic that Odin had long aspired to master.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Freya married Odin? What was in it for her?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It was a sacrifice to protect the people - a selfless act of love. Truly, she deserves better than she got. But of course there’s more to that story.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head, how do we speak to the serpent?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: There’s a horn on a platform of the middle point of the bridge. Take me to it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Finally! That Horn!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Good. Now put my lips to the horn.
[He blow the horn and the World Serpent begins to bite off Thor’s statue.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why’s he doing that?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Odin had that statue made in honour of Thor. Seeing as the World Serpent absolutely abhors the fat dobber, he was probably sick of looking at it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But… doesn’t that hurts?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, he and Thor have a bit of a unpleasant history between them… or they will anyway. so I guess waking up to see it was worse then the thought of lumps of solid stone passing through his gullet. You want to ask him?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. Our only concern is Jötunheim.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: All right, wish me luck! Yooooooor-moooooooo hin meeee-meeeeeeeeer.
[The World Serpent answer him something.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’ve still got it, lads. He remembers me. Lyooooooooo- Oh no! That’s not it! Uh… Maaaaaw-lon-gooooo vih-nooooor kooooon tooooon kooooon. Oh dear. Ehhhhhh-kooooo… noooooh oh-thooooo voo-nooooor…
[The World Serpent answer him something.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He knows the pain for your loss. He will help you.
[The World Serpent speaks something.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Efni… ooooo-fooooon-goooor. Curious…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is it?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ohhh… Nothing to be concerned about.
[The World Serpent begins to push the bridge on which the heroes stand.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: W-What’s he doing?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Making sure we’re heading in the right direction. Listen closely now… we need two things to get us into the land of the Giants. First, we need to learn the travel rune that opens realm travel to Jötunheim. Second, we need to carve that rune into the other special gateway.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That one on the peak where we first met you?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Correct. Except the Giants, in their infinite wisdom saw to it that no ordinary chisel would do the job. Only the tip of a magical chisel opens that gate. Luckily, I know where it is and it’s not far.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He looked kind of mad for a moment there.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah, that. You felt I said that you were friends of Odin. You’ll forgive me - I’ve never spoken of the Ancient Tongue sober.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait, look! The water’s drop even further! You can see more of the realm towers and statues. I even see new places to explore along the shore.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Where is this chisel?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Find me a boar and we’ll go from there.
[A NEW DESTINATION COMPLETED.]
[Kratos goes to a huge brazier and asks Atreus to try again to read the inscription on it.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ah! I can read what this says now… but… it’s a name. Eir!
[The brazier ignites a bright flame.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa! The name made it light up…!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It’s the name of one of the Valkyries. That’s quite curious.
[The heroes board in the boat.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Which way to the chisel?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Keep rolling towards the statues of the oarsmen, then thread past between them.
[They met Sindri along the way.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: I have a favor to ask. Just a small favor, really. Do you remember the dagger you gave me?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The dagger stabbed into the reaver’s back? Whose own son killed him? Yea, I haven’t forgotten that one.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Well, I traced it to a group of Reavers that operate out of the Northri Stronghold. I’d wager that’s where they took away the haul from Fafnir’s Storeroom. Along with that whetstone… that I could use… to help you?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hrnnn. Another treasure hunt. Pointless.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, not if Sindri really can make us better equipment with that whetstone. Plus… the reaver’s son. He MURDERED his father! Hey Sindri. Have you met Mimir?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: If you mean the severed head that keeps blinking with me, please keep it away. There’s no possible way if that’s hygienic.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ach! That’s nice. Lovely to see you too, Sindri! Knob.
[Traveling on one of the islands they find a massive door behind which a huge dragon was imprisoned.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah, Fafnir! I always wondered what became of him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait; Fafnir? Like, Fafnir’s Storeroom Fafnir?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The very one.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But Sindri said he was a dwarf!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He was! And now he’s a dragon. Funny how life works, innit?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He’s chained up.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Perhaps we should keep an eye out for binding shrines and free the poor bastard, aye lads?
[Kratos destroys the first shrine.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How did your friend became a dragon, Mimir?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, he’s no friend of mine. This little scrote was a constant source of annoyance amongst Aesir and Vanir alike.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then why free him?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Trust the recently liberated, brother; No one deserves to be held captive like this. Even a greedy little Dwarf-come-dragon.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You never answered the boy’s question, Head; how did this dwarf became a dragon?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, I don’t know for certain, though, I’d wager his penchant for stealing the magical artifacts had something to do with it. Must’ve stolen a trinket from the wrong Vanir goddess.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What do we do with that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hmm… We will show it to the Dwarves.
[Kratos destroys the last shrine.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Time to set him free. Think he’ll remember you?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I don’t know, lad. A lot’s changed since we last cross paths. I had legs!
[Atreus destroy the seal on Fafnir’s chains.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: There you go, you wee little bugger.
[Fafnir roars.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Be free.
[Fafnir flies away.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well! Turning dragon hasn’t done much for his personality.
[Back to the boat.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can’t believe Odin and Freya were ever married.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Love and hate are more closely intertwined than you might imagine. For instance, Odin hates the Giants, and they him, but Thor’s own mother was the Giantess Fjörgyn - one of Odin’s great loves.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So Thor is half-God and half-Giant? Weird…!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Once Fjörgyn was gone, lonely ages past for Odin… and as war with the Vanir raged, I could see that he really wanted beneath his bluster. And after no small amount of convincing, Freya agreed. For a while there, he really turned on the charm. He seems happy. He seemed interested in making her happy. He grunted her so many wishes I can scarcely recall them all. The peace held, and I truly believed all had worked out better than I could have planned. But Odin’s true face showed itself again in the end. Oh he won Freya’s trust, and she taught him some of her Vanir magic - another choice she would live to bitterly regret. Sadly, despite his wise chancellor’s best efforts to persuade him that peace was the only true path to stave off Ragnarök, Odin never let go of his obsession with Jötunheim. The taste of Vanir magic led him to new forms of experimentation, and new levels of depravity.
[They’re landing on a small island and heard that someone is moaning…]

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Gullveig… You were taken from this realm too early. You, who walks among the living! My beloved Gullveig calls to me… she yearns for peace! Yet he remains lie in pieces. I beg of you, make my Gullveig whole again!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You want us to collect her bones? Gross.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Gullveig’s seiðr magick knows no bounds. She can reunite you with those you’ve lost!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Really? How?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy…

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I can smell you grief, child… Rest assured, her magic is strong enough to create bridges between life and death… If only for a short while.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy! We’re leaving.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: They’ve taken three of sweat Gullveig’s bones, and spread them across the lake. Bring me her bones, child! Gullveig will reward you!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father… maybe we should look for those bones?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Didn’t you hear him? We could talk to Mom again. If we keep an eye out while we-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Look if you wish, boy! I will not be distracted by this fool’s errand.
[They board the boat.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This chisel we seek- what is it?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’m glad you asked actually. I have just the story for you…  There was a giant once named Thamur- a very giant Giant- who, despite his mountainous size, was without question the greatest stonemason this world had ever seen. Proud Thamur hoped to one day pass his vast knowledge on to his son, but young Hrimthur had he heart of a warrior. Perhaps the father had too much fear in him, the son too little… either way, a quarrel of theirs spiralled out of control, and the overworked stonemason-bonk!-struck his son. Hrimthur ran off into the night. Feeling shame and regret, Thamur chased after his son, but in his emotional state, soon found himself wandering Midgard, lost and alone. Sadly, he caught the eye of the one person he didn’t want to meet alone at night, so far from home… Thor.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Thor killed him. Oh no… He fell on a village?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye. When Thamur fell, he crushed a charming place famed for worshipping the Vanir god, Njörd. Thor always took credit for planning that one, but the truth is the sweaty bawbag just got lucky.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What happened to the survivors?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, Thamur was a Frost Giant. When he died, his final breath froze everything.
[They finally find the Giant… it’s hard to describe his size. Just one of his palms alone looks like a huge mountain.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There he is…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Find the tip of a chisel. That’s the magic we need.
[They come to the Giant’s head.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How we getting down there?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have a plan.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You do?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do not act so surprised.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: No offense, brother, but I don’t even think Thor with Mjolnir in hand could get through that much ice.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then Thor is a fool.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: This should be entertaining…
[They are attacked by several opponents.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ready.
[They kill them without much problems.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh, hey. You again. Come on up! Wow, that was… uh… something, that uh, fight. Here, catch.
[He throws Kratos an apple. He puts forward his ax and cuts it.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Well, that was a waste of a perfectly good apple.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How were you not seen? There is nowhere here to hide.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ah. That. It’s a little trick my people can pull… a special way of not being seen.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You can be invisible?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: More like I can step into the realm between realms… and your mind doesn’t understand what it’s seeing, so it sees nothing at all. That’s how we avoids ever having to actually use the weapons we craft. It, uh… It doesn’t seem to work on dragons though.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Your brother wanted to know if you were getting enough to eat. I guess I can tell him you are!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Brok was asking about me? Was there mead on his breath?
[Kratos throws his ax millimeter from Sindri’s head.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You let him touch this again. Come on then…
[He barely lifts the axe and drag it to his workshop.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So that’s how Brok was in the temple right after the water dropped. He stepped between realms!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Okay, now shush! I need complete silence for this…
[He hits the axe once with a hammer.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: There ya go!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Rrrrn.
[The axe improved. Kratos puts it away and goes to clear the way.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Careful! My shop’s RIGHT HERE!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There is something over there!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ughff, the Travellers. Woahgff. Disgusting. Ughff. Smelly. Covered in god knows how many little beasties. But gorgeous armor! Let’s see if I can’t make something more sanitary, yes?
[He notices one of the arrows he gave to Atreus.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Why… is that a piece of my braided mistletoe arrow adorning your quiver strap? A little memento of your good pal Sindri? I’m so… terribly touched.
[Kratos continue his search for the chisel.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir? You know this place?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, came here on a diplomatic mission once, trying to broker a peace between Asgard and Vanaheim. That war- so many lives lost. What I didn’t know was Thor had already gone on a killing spree of Giants.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What did the Giants have to do with the war between the gods?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Nothing at all, lad, that’s the tragedy of it. They took no side in that madness… but Odin’s paranoia is surpassed only by Thor’s lust for blood.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hmm. Ooh, we got most of it…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well! A stealthy plan it is not.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now we must free the other strap.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We do? Why are we going up when what we need is all the way down there?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Think.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well… the chisel tip is under thick layers of ice, so melting it won’t work.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Correct.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And there weren’t any Shatter Crystals nearby for me to shoot, so that’s not an option.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Correct.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That just loves smashing the ice. But we’d need something ridiculously heavy to - Ohhhhh. I get it now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Good.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How are we going to turn the hammer so it lands near the chisel tip?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not possible. We cut it free, ride it down, and figure out what comes next after.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So your plan involves a whole bunch of luck then.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You are welcome to suggest a different one.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Þruma!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hold tight.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Uh. This plan seems ill-advised.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Quiet, head. JUMP!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That didn’t work. It only fell a little ways. Oh no. The floor’s collapsed. There’s a sand bowl, but how do we get to it?
[They find a way.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What does it say?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “When time itself is disarrayed / The forward path is retrograde.” Retrograde? It’s backwards?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Those symbols… the seasons?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah. But the order’s all jumbled. Shouldn’t it be “Winter, Spring Summer, Autumn”?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why start with “Winter"?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s from a song mother used to sing.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh! I know that one! Winter-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Quiet, head.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Doesn’t like music either… got it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Haust! Sumar! Vetr! Yes!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus. That word.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Þola. It means, “endure”.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Try it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Þola! We’re rising! The energy’s lifting the platform!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Keep writing.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Þola!… Þola!… Þola!…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head. How is this possible?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: My guess? Temporal magic. Dangerous stuff the high van sods used to play around - with the ability to freeze time! Happened to be a favorite of Njörd himself, in fact.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Used to?” Why did they stop?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well… turns out stopping time keeps the sun and moon from streaking across the sky. Unfortunately it does NOT stop the wolves that chase them – always looking to sink their teeth in. After that they decided it was best to leave the time alone.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can’t get to the bowl! Father – the bowl dropped away! We’re collapsing!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: JUMP!!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whew.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You did well.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Thanks!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The boy…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Just having a little fun, you big grump.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well there it is. How we’re going to get it free?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: A push.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Trust me. Ready? Dig in and push with everything.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir.
[They push away some huge piece of mountain.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How do we get down?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We jump!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Really?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come! Do not panic!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why would I panic?! Whoa!!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have you!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You’re cracked, you know that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hhng. You are well?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Uh huh.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Good. We should keep moving.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow… The chisel tip!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Give the man credit. He has a talent for destroying things.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Remember that, head.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Never leaves my mind…

Speaker: Voice 1
Text: Where are they?! Ugh. I fucking hate Midgard. How do we know they’re even here? Because that hammer didn’t fall on its own.

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: Well… If we find them, I get the kid, right?

Speaker: Voice 1
Text: What is the matter with you?

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: I smell a dwarf. Find him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Those were the guys we saw with Baldur. His nephews?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye. Magni and Modi - the sons of Thor.

Speaker: Atreus
