Text: Mother always said the Aesir were the worst of the gods, and Thor was the worst of the Aesir. Guess he’s a terrible father, too.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: They are no longer children. They have no excuse.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Will Sindri be okay?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: They’ll never even see him. Ah, the great dining hall. Envy of all Midgard. Funny. I remember there being a massive candelabrum. Really livened up the place…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Shh-something ahead…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: See, lad? He’s fine.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Thought it best to vanish when Thor’s idiot sons showed up.

Speaker: Voice 1
Text: Will you focus on your damn job and quit that shit.

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: You quit that shit. I mean it!

Speaker: Voice 1
Text: He went to war with Uncle and walked away.

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: Maybe. Uncle hasn’t seen straight in years.

Speaker: Voice 1
Text: Well, as long as father believes him, so do we. So you will stop talking, focus, and help me find them. Can’t disappoint father!

Speaker: Voice 2
Text: Oh, I’ll smack you boy.

Speaker: Voice 1
Text: No, we cannot disappoint father. Now keep looking!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Once you retrieve the whetstone, please take utmost care while handling it. It is a precious relic, after all.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Hurry, brother. We may get a piece of the chisel and be gone before they even notice. Uh oh.

Speaker: Magni
Text: You.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy-

Speaker: Magni
Text: Surrender. The Allfather demands it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.

Speaker: Magni
Text: Good.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This fight is mine, boy. GO.

Speaker: Modi
Text: And where do you think you’re goin’? Oh no, Brother! The little freak’s got a bow! What are we gonna do? The small one is yours, Brother.

Speaker: Magni
Text: Don’t tell me what to do, Brother. I will cripple you! I’ll take the small one. I can’t remember the last time we faced an actual challenge.

Speaker: Modi
Text: You call this a challenge? An old man and this stillborn lamb?

Speaker: Magni
Text: Unbelievable. You mean to oppose the might of Asgard?

Speaker: Modi
Text: Brother - the Snowblind!

Speaker: Both
Text: ÓÐR BRÓÐIR BLINDR! (MAD BLIND BROTHER!]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can’t see!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stay behind me, boy. Why do you hunt us? What does Odin want?

Speaker: Modi
Text: Don’t know. Don’t care. Come ’ere, half-breed. You’re done holding daddy’s hand.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Shut up! Don’t call me that!

Speaker: Modi
Text: Can’t believe you’ve lasted this long. Those skinny little arms can barely lift the bow.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I said SHUT UP!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Calm yourself, boy.

Speaker: Magni
Text: Looks like they need another lesson, brother.

Speaker: Modi
Text: Oh, I’m more than happy to teach, brother. You… you’re mine.

Speaker: Magni
Text: Got big plans for you, kid. Look at you… weak… scrawny. I bet daddy’s embarrassed to have drag you around.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Shut up! Shut it out.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Focus.

Speaker: Magni
Text: Let’s see how good you are with that bow after I break all your fingers.

Speaker: Modi
Text: Hey Magni, look what I caught!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh no! He’s got your son!

Speaker: Both
Text: ÓÐR BRÓÐIR BLINDR! (MAD BLIND BROTHER!]

Speaker: Magni
Text: Your mother ugly or something? Se cut up your face so you’d look like her?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Don’t talk about my mother!

Speaker: Magni
Text: “Don’t talk about my mommy!” Pathetic.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Don’t listen to him, lad. He’s trying to rile you up.

Speaker: Magni
Text: Idiots! The Sons of Thor will destroy you.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The Sons of Thor are welcome to try!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Sorry. Overstepped, yeah?

Speaker: Modi
Text: Gonna drag your carcass to Asgard.

Speaker: Modi
Text: Try again, asshole.

Speaker: Magni
Text: Let’s do this! What’s the matter? Does the little runt want his mommy?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Stop it!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy! Stay focused.

Speaker: Magni
Text: The small one is mine. Cry for mommy, boy. What - did mommy not feed you enough? Too ugly to let you suck on her-

Speaker: Atreus
Text: SHUT UP, YOU BASTARD!!!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus!

Speaker: Magni
Text: I got the runt. HRYAA!

Speaker: Modi
Text: Oh, Mimir- don’t think we’ve forgotten about you.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Leave him alone!

Speaker: Magni
Text: You jealous? Want me all to yourself, do you?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Kráku lið! (Shitty crew!]

Speaker: Modi
Text: Fuck off! Let’s finish this, Magni!

Speaker: Both
Text: ÓÐR BRÓÐIR BLINDR! (MAD BLIND BROTHER!]

Speaker: Magni
Text: Wow, kid… your mother must have been some whore to lay with the likes of him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’LL KILL you!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: ATREUS! Control yourself!
[He split Marni’s head in half.]

Speaker: Modi
Text: Magni! NO-!! How did you…?
[Kratos slowly moving towards him. Modi backs away.]

Speaker: Modi
Text: You have no idea what… You son of a bitch!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You’re next!
[Modi runs away.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Come back, you damn coward! I’ll rip your head off!! GAAH!!!! (coughs with blood]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The sickness… the fever has returned.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No! It hasn’t…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The coughing… the blood… The boy’s sick. He needs Freya.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: NO.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Steady…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’ll be all right…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: There you go, lad…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m fine. See?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: We should keep an eye on him.
[Kratos chops off a piece of the chisel.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Enough?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Should do. With that, we can carve the travel rune to Jötunhelm – get you where you need to go. Identically, all those magically-sealed doors we’ve seen can now be unlocked… like that one around the corner. You can get through that door , now that you got the chisel.
[THE MAGIC CHISEL COMPLETED.]
[Kratos opens the door and walks in.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You… killed Magni.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That he did.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He was a god… but you killed him.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Minor Aesir, perhaps, but aye…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And his father is Thor…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not Minor. Not Minor at all, him. This will not go over well in Asgard.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I defended us. Nothing more. I fear no judgement.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Judgement, no, but if vengeance is any concern…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Since when can you kill a god…?  Wait, we were here before. But which way back? (coughing]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I don’t think the lad’s doing too well.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m fine… Nothing to worry about.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If so, then keep up.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes sir. Hey… I just realised… Magni didn’t come back to life.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That is interesting, It’s known the Aesir find their own way to Valhalla. No Valkyrie escort, no processing at the gates of Helheim. That may be significant…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look - we’re back near the giant’s hand. What… what is this place?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Fishermen would bring the day’s catch into this port and use that contraption to send some of it directly to the jarl’s main kitchen. The rest were sorted and sold.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There is an exit under the thumb. Find a way across.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s moving. (coughs]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Back under his palm. We’re almost there.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Everything we just did.… climbed around a dead giant, rode a giant falling hammer, fought some bad gods. What do you think mother would say?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That you have come a long way.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Thanks.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Another one here.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah - you know this one, don’t you?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s Thamur--the giant Stonemason! Is he building a wall around Jötunheim?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It was to be his masterwork. He only wanted to protect his people…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Too bad the first part got burned.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’d prefer the last panel was burned. Such a senseless pity…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This place. It feels like…. like a prison.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That would explain the hefty magical lock on the outside.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But it’s more than that. I have this feeling… like something is waiting for us down here.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You’ve a knack for ominous statements, lad.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What kind of something?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m not sure. Something powerful.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Whatever you feel, boy… we will handle it. We have come this far, yes?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, father.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: A Valkyrie… imprisoned? She actually did it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: A Valkyrie? But I thought they were just spirits.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Take caution, lads. A Valkyrie in the flesh… I can’t think of a more formidable opponent.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She does not attack.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Does she even know we’re here? Whoah! I think she knows we’re here now! Okay, here we go!
[Kratos defeat a Valkyrie named Gunnr.]

Speaker: Gunnr
Text: You have freed me from my corrupted form. You have my eternal gratitude, but my sister remain trapped as I was. Take my helm. Find them. Free them. The fate of the Valkyries rests on your shoulders.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The fate of the Valkyries…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Sound pretty important.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That’s putting it mildly, lad.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What do you know of them?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: A fair question. And yet, no one easily answered. I know more that most, but much of their history is veiled in secrecy. My own experience with the Valkyries ends with my imprisonment.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You are avoiding the question, Head.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: As I said, brother… it’s complicated. I don’t know why of how they’ve become such wrenched creatures… but perhaps if we can free more of them…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You want us to fight more of those things?!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: “The fate of the Valkyries.” lad. A more worthy endeavour, there is not.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It will be dangerous.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, that hasn’t stopped you before, aye?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Mrrrnnn…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That’s the spirit! What now then? Maybe Freya ought to have a look at the boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No, I feel better now. I just needed to catch my breath. Where do we go next?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, now that we’ve got the Giant’s chisel, we need to learn the travel rune to Jötunheim so we can carve it into that special gateway atop the peak, and open realm travel to the land of the Giants.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You don’t know it?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Alas, no- but the Serpent did mention that the Giants had entrusted that secret to Týr.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Isn’t Týr dead?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, but his hidden vault is very much in reach. The doors are beneath his temple, submerged in the lake for generations until our snake-friend shifted his weight. There we shall find the fabled “Black Rune of Jötunheim”…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We could also explore some more. We got that chisel now, and that vault isn’t going anywhere. Seems a shame to waste the boat.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We shall see, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay, obviously the marriage with Odin didn’t last. But how did Freya end up a hermit in the woods?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, that was a singular piece of cruelty, even for Odin. As if the marriage wasn’t punishment enough! Freya was better to him than he deserved. She stuck it out through all manner of indignity, all in the name of maintaining peace, and safety for her people. But Odin’s madness, his tyranny, his corruption of her magicks- it became more than she could stomach, and at long last she broke it off. Odin’s wrath was fierce, and his curses upon her were more than she’d dared to fear.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But her magic was so much stronger than his…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: After so much time together, he knew her vulnerabilities, and exploited them to craft curses she could never break.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh… like not being able to leave Midgard.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Worse still, he robbed her of her warrior spirit. Freya cannot fight--even to defend herself. No living thing way she harm, by blade nor spell. In a world this belligerent, what choice does she have but isolation!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Poor Freya… I guess if I was her, I’d spit in your face too.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, lad. So would I.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: These bones pulse with magic…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It must be Gullveig! Could we… could we just hold onto it? Maybe we’ll find the rest of them.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This Spirit lies to you, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How would you know?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have known many spirits. They are all liars.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This one is different. I know it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You “know” very little. Trusting a spirit to keep its word is foolish, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But, if there’s even a chance… Don’t you want to see Mom again?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Of course I- She is gone, Atreus. You must accept this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I do, but… to see her again, just one more time…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why do you believe him? You do not know him, or who he was. All of this is sinister.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He wants to see someone he loved again. I… I understand how it feels. I don’t think there’s anything sinister about it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hope is blinding your instincts, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow… It’s like there was an entire city under the water!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, lad. A forgotten city.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What was it called?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Erm, well… I forgot!

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Bothvar… Frømund… Eric…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Are you okay?

Speaker: Spirit
Text: No, son. My goods are underwater. My men are drowned. And yet, their bodies continue to walk the beaches.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hel-Walkers. They plague these lands.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I was their captain. They died because of me. But these abominations sully their memories. I will find a way to free them from their tortured state. In this, I am determined. A thunderstorm scattered all three of my ships across the lake. I know not what I did to anger Thor… but his judgement was swift and brutal. I discovered opportunities for hunting and trade in these lands. I gave my search for Jötunheim long ago. Leave that for the younger, more helpful men.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Gullveig’s bones.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What will you say to her?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: To Gullveig?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Your mother. What have you left unsaid?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I… I guess I… I just want to know if she’s okay.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She is dead, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I know that! I… You don’t understand.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Neither do you.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I felt blessed to lead such a loyal crew. We’d become a family over the years. And now… my family is cursed.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What would you say to Mom?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Nothing.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nothing?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There is nothing left to say.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What about everything we’ve done so far? That man coming to the house… Talking to the World Serpent… We’ve done so many amazing things. I just want to tell her about them. Don’t you?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What else would you say to her?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’d tell her that we’re both okay. Not to worry about.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus, I… I miss her too. You know this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I thought I “knew very little.” Mimir- there was a shrine about a Glant lady, with lots of books, and visions…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah, that would be Gróa, the knowledge Keeper. She was a gifted sorceress who gathered every tome or arcane wisdom she could find in the realms, all in the hopes of augmenting her powers of prophecy that she might find her lost husband, Aurvandil. But it was not her husband she would glimpse in her visions- for it was Gróa, sending longer and farther than any before or since, who witnessed Ragnarök- the end and the beginning. When Odin caught word of her ultimate prophecy, he maneuvered to obtain her knowledge and hoard it for himself. Gróa knew Odin as a longtime patron of her services, and so she welcomed him into her library as a friend. What she did not know is that Odin himself was behind her husband’s disappearance, having used is enchantments to conceal his death at Thor’s hands from her sight. Smiling, jealous Odin took her by the throat, and with his very hands he stole her library and her life for his own.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I always knew Odin was bad. But that’s just…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ruthless? Barbaric? Heartless? That’s Odin. In fact, we would do well to sit here in silence for the next few moments and reflect on Odin’s capacity for cruelty. And so-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Reflect longer. Boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir! Hey, it’s another treasure map!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The final bone.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We might as well return them to the Spirit. Maybe he will keep his word, and-

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I know she’s not coming back, okay! I just… Nevermind.  Let’s just go return the bones.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head… you are full of stories. When will you tell one that entertains?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I beg your pardon!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He just insulted you.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Yeah, I got that. So you want a corker, do ya? Very well, my brothers- I’ll tell you the story of Hrungnir the Brawler. The real story.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There was a huge battle, right? His shrine had him in the middle, fighting off Aesir…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: A pretty story, but… no. Hrungnir, you see, was born with neither head nor heart, so the Giants had to complete him with stone. He was strong, to be sure- but also a perfect simpleton. Odin met him wandering in Midgard one day- found him so amusing, so harmless, so gullible, that he invites him back to his palace in Asgard. There he gives Hrungnir his full of mead, and goads him into all manner of boast and antics, all for the amusement of the court. I was there- I saw the Aesir laugh as Hrungnir leapt upon his shield and swore he’d kill us all and take our womenfolk tack to Jötunheim. Then Thor shows up- and does he laugh? Oh, no. Thor takes one look at the drunken stone buffoon, and brings down Mjölnir on his head so hard that he’s got chunks of Hrungnir in his own skull to this day. Thor is so startled by the faceful of rock, he doesn’t notice Hrungnir’s body topple right onto him with sickening crunch! And again, the roars of laughter echo through the palace halls!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s an awful story, Mimir. Nothing like the ones mother told me.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Let that be a lesson, m’son- truth is seldom so pretty as myth and legend.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I wonder why Gullveig’s bones are all over the place?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: For desecration, typically. Pieces of scattered corpse make for a piss poor soul. No hope for Valhalla or Helheim when your arm’s on one beach and your head’s on another.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why not ask the Spirit? I am sure he will be forthcoming with answers.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I have a question. If Ymir was the First Giant, where did he come from?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: In the beginning, there was Ginnungagap, the great void. There were no realms yet, only primordial forces. There was Fire, and there was Ice, and there in the Void they met, and produced…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Water?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: More than water - the mystic life blood of something entirely now. From this water, Ymir took form, and became a being of pure creation and chaos, mother and father to all that came after.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Even the Aesir?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, every god, man, and beast came first from Ymir’s flesh. Though it was the Aesir who thought themselves so superior that they should hold dominion over the rest of creation. It was Odin who took arms against his creator, and spilled Ymir’s life-blood with his spear. A necessary evil, he would say, to bring Order to the realms. From Ymir’s torn flesh, Odin would fashion the realm of Midgard for his own. Called himself “Allfather” - as if he was the creator, and not the creator’s destroyer. A small… covetous… tyrant…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir…?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Mm? Oh, sorry, m’boy. You know, I think it best we just end it there actually.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay, I know I saw something.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I saw it too.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Freya did say the Jötunheim realm tower was missing from the lake. But maybe only kinda?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Very strange indeed…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We have collected the rest of your woman’s corpse, Spirit. Show us this magic you have promised!

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Ꭺhhh! My sweet Gullveig… whole again. Rise, dear Gullveig. AWAKEN, OH POWERFUL GULLVEIG!

Speaker: Gullveig
Text: Evni ykkarr biðjast…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: She says she will honour our request!

Speaker: Gullveig
Text: Eldi-fagnað…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And reunite us…

Speaker: Gullveig
Text: Inn dauðr!!! (…in death!]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: OK… You were right.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Focus up, boy!
[They defeat Gullveig.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Alright. Say it. “I told you so.”

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I told you so.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “You are a naive, foolish boy.”

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This is true as well. But do not take your disappointment out on me, boy. Take it as a lesson.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oooh… Týr’s vault is behind that magical lock! I can’t believe we ‘re setting foot in Týr’s vault! Another one of these. It’s Týr! But… the middle panel is missing. Wait, I thought Týr was a god, not a giant.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye. But he was loved by everyone, including the giants. Other than me, he was the only one they gifted with their special sight. Hey… I wonder if the giants left a triptych about me somewhere too?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Go ahead.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Actually… come look. Let me show you how to read this.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That us not necess-

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You’ve taught me so much. Let me teach you something.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Come on. You already speak it. Learning to read won’t be that hard.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I know how to read, boy. Just not this tongue.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You’re halfway there already then. Okay… so the runes represent a lot of different things. Some gods, some animals, and some are-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Wait.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh, am I going too fast? Sorry I’ll-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not that. Do you smell something?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah, I do. Smells like- rain?
[A lighting strikes at them. Modi enters and put Kratos into lightning chains.]

Speaker: Modi
Text: You ruined everything. I earned that fucking hammer, but now everyone’s gonna think I only got it ‘cause Magni’s gone. I’ll be a joke. But if I kill you-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Arrrgh!

Speaker: Modi
Text: …no one’s gonna laugh at me.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No!
[He shot at Modi but it jut make him angrier.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: ARRRGH!

Speaker: Modi
Text: Wow, are you dumb. That your father’s doing or did you get it from your mom? She stupid and ugly?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Shut up!
[He trying to attack Modi with a knife. Modi dodges and hits Atreus with his shield.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You don’t… know anything… about my mother.

Speaker: Modi
Text: Oh that’s true. But I’m gonna get to know you really well. You’re gonna be my new brother… right after I finish killing your father.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Rrrrgh!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: STOP IT!
[Atreus screams and flames appear on his chest. I dare say it was the Spartan Rage, Kratos’ signature ability.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: RAAAAAAAA!!!
[He faints almost immediately.]

Speaker: Modi
Text: Whoops… I think I broke him.
[Kratos slowly stands up…]

Speaker: Modi
Text: No… Stay back!
[Kratos takes away his sparkling stick and punch Modi in the chest as hard as he can.]

Speaker: Modi
Text: No… This isn’t over!
[Modi runs away.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Brother… the boy.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You have to get him to Freya quickly! There’s no other way.
[BEHIND THE LOCK COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Take the boat. Freya’s isn’t far. Odin’s eye is on you, brother. Especially now that you’ve taken to killing his kin. Freya’s forest is a blind spot for him. This is our smartest move. And if anyone can heal him, it’s her.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is happening to him?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’ve seen it in mortals, that some conflict of the mind expresses itself as an ailment of the body.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. The fever burns hotter. He is shaking,

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It’s serious. We must hurry.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Freya! Open the door! We need your help! Woman, do you hear me? It is urgent!

Speaker: Freya
Text: I am still a god! Go away.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The boy has fallen ill! Freya!
[She immediately opens.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He is ill.

Speaker: Freya
Text: Inside. This is no ordinary illness. The boy’s true nature, your true nature, fights within him.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I did this to him…? Will you help me?

Speaker: Freya
Text: Of course… There is a rare ingredient found only in Helheim. The keeper that protects the Bridge of The Damned. I need its heart.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hel…

Speaker: Freya
Text: The Realm of the Dead. Do you know it?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not this one…

Speaker: Freya
Text: It is a land of unyielding cold. Fires cannot burn there, and no magic in all the nine realms can create a blaze. As for the dead… your frost axe will be useless. You’ll need to find something else.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then I must return home… dig up a past I swore would stay buried.

Speaker: Freya
Text: Who you were before doesn’t matter. This boy is not your past he is your son… and he needs his father. This rune opens the bridge to Helheim. When you are there, do not under any circumstances cross the Bridge of The Damned. There is no road back. Understand?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: (groans]

Speaker: Freya
Text: Boy… Heimili! (Home!) You must hurry. Through my garden there’s a path leading to my boat. Take it. Return home. Dig up your past. Do whatever you need to do. Just bring me back the bridge keeper’s heart, and your son may survive. Now…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Freya… When last we spoke… I was…

Speaker: Freya
Text: No. You are right to distrust the word of a god. No need to explain. Not to me. Not for that. I will keep him safe. That’s a mother’s promise.
[He’s leaving the witch’s house.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Helheim, of all places… You alright, brother?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I will do what I must. Leave me be.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: As you wish.
[Once in the boat, he goes back to his house… The Spitit of Athena silently accompany him.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Athena… Get out of my head.

[Coming home, he pulls out from the basement his legendary blades wrapped in Greek fabric. Kratos with an uneasy heart touches them carefully. His chain wounds whine with pain. Athena appears in the doorway.]

Speaker: Spirit of Athena
Text: There’s nowhere you can hide, Spartan. Put as much distance between you and the truth as you want, it changes nothing. Pretend to be everything you are not… teacher… husband… father… but there is one unavoidable truth you will never escape: You cannot change. You will always be a monster.
[Kratos equip his blades.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I know. But I am your monster no longer.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Alright, brother… let’s see what those blades can do. Left side, brother! Right flank! Watch your right! My, yes… those blades will serve quite well in Helheim. Now. I believe I see a door to the Realm Between Realms over there - in your front yard no less! Take the shortcut back to the realm travel temple, then on to Helheim, yeah? Well, I’m pretty sure you weren’t talking to me back there. Anything you’d like to get off your chest, brother? I can assure you I’m unsurpassed in keeping confidences. Well, you know where to find me. And for the record, I’d already guessed you were Greek. “Athena?” Dead giveaway.

Speaker: Brok
Text: What? Hey! You reek of foreign magick. Sweet Nanna’s nethers, what are those…? I have never seen the like… That’s you be a family heirloom…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: NO. Nor will it ever be.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Son, my brother and me created Mjölnir for the big idiot… I know from quality. And them… them’s special. I say, where’s the little turd?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He has fallen ill.

Speaker: Brok
Text: No… What happened? Aesir?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. The fault is mine… and my responsibility to make it right.

Speaker: Brok
Text: We all gotta take responsibility sometimes, huh? Say, what can I do to help him? I can do things. You want I should tag along?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. You work here… is enough.

Speaker: Brok
Text: All right. So where you off to in such a hurry?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The realm of the dead.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Helheim?!? Shit… this is serious. I’ll be keeping my eyes on you…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Now that Freya’s given you the travel rune to Helheim, it should be unlocked on the table. And it’s done. We really are doing this.

Speaker: Brok
Text: I’ll be watching your back!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Let me take this moment to tell you what you are about to do is absolutely insane. Not even Odin can survive this cold, so I hope those blades work.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Is this the bridge Freya spoke of?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: No, we’re still on the realm travel bridge. We’re after the Bridge of the Damned. The dead use it to cross into their permanent home, the city of Helheim. The bridge keeper who minds admission - he’s the one we want. Just follow this bridge… should lead us straight to him. Do You know… I’d really hope never to see this place again. Use the fire of your blades to burn away that Hel’s Bramble blocking the path. See that? One of the many reasons we went back for those blades… Oh, this is all wrong. Only the newly-dead should be here. There’s too many The gate must be closed… and if the gate’s closed, then it’s true-Hel’s full up. Without the Valkyrie to sort and cull them, Hel is overwhelmed.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: When we killed the reavers near my home… they came here? How did they return so quickly?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Time doesn’t move the same between all realms, especially where the spirit world is concerned.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Like the light of Alfheim…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The opposite, in fact… the Lake of Souls feels faster than Alfheim time, but Hel is much slower than Midgard. Sorry, I’m sure that’s confusing-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If we will be back to my son all the sooner, that is good.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah! Aren’t you a quick study.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This Valhalla… is it within Hel?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh no, no- Valhalla is part of Asgard. Only the worthy dead go there, the warriors who die in glorious combat. Hel is for those who die in dishonour.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Criminals.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, and those dead of disease, mishap, age…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is dishonourable to grow old?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, never too late to go out fighting, I suppose.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Will killing the Bridge Keeper help the dead leave Midgard?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I don’t expect it will. Though I don’t suppose it will make things any worse, either. It’ll be one less obstacle for the living to reach the inner sanctum of Helheim… but who’d be mad enough to go there? The Bridge of the Damned. And there’s the keeper making sure the dead are really dead.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is that he holds?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That totem contains a powerful source of magical energy-the very power of Helheim itself. But what you want is his heart. Just take it and we can leave.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Start some trouble. You can do that, right?
[Kratos defeat the keeper named MÁTTUGR HELSON (MIGHTY SON OF HEL).]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Now the heart, brother. You’ll have to get your hands dirty.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have the heart. I need nothing more?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You’re set. But better not to linger here though, eh?
[Something big and ominous appears in the distance.]

Speaker: Voice
Text: Kratos.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Zeus?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Zeus?!?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: My father…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Your father was Zeus?!? That explains a lot.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is that place?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Never go there. Understand?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How is he here? That is not possible.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It’s just an illusion. Hel’s known for torturing its inhabitants with their own past. We should focus on getting back to your son.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Pssst.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aah!

Speaker: Brok
Text: Sshhh! I ain’t supposed to be here. S’cold! Real quick, gimme your blades.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why?

Speaker: Brok
Text: I said I’d help you and I aim to. C’mon!
[Kratos gives him his blades.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: My equipment’s in Midgard. Be right back.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You… you don’t suppose he nicked those, do you?

Speaker: Brok
Text: There! Now they’re ready for the Winds of Hel. Just target this magical glowy bit here with your blades and throw. No target that wind trap with your blades- It’s that little ball hanging in the middle of the door, see it? Just let ‘er loose. Now target that wind trap with your blades. See there? See that? Now you can absorb and release the Winds of Hel whenever it damn pleases you, so you’re welcome and I’m leaving. This place is cold enough to freeze pair of pigeon eggs.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I sometimes wonder if there was once some sort of accident in his brain.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We have been away too long.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Sorry, brother… I am stuck on what I heard back there. Zeus was your father?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now now. We should focus on getting out of Hel.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: And with that I cannot argue. I’ll just contemplate that little nugget in silence then.
[Kratos goes back to Brok’s workshop.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: You made it! Better get home to your boy already!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: We shouldn’t delay, brother-it’s straight back to Midgard with that heart. Your father was Zeus. I finally understand. I’m dangling from the hip of the bloody Ghost of Sparta.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do NOT call me that.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Don’t mistake me, brother. From what I heard the pantheon had it coming, But it’s still a bit to take in. I knew you hate gods, but you really can’t stay away from them, can you?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You must say nothing to the boy. He must never know.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Bollocks, brother, respectfully, bollocks. He has to know. He’ll never be whole without the truth. Look. I get it. You hate the gods. All gods. It’s no accident that includes yourself. And it includes your boy, don’t you see that? He feels that! He can’t help what he is. He can’t begin to help it, because you haven’t even told him. It’s all connected, man!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You… will tell him nothing.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Very well.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Hey, so you know that shortcut between realms? Well, I made it better! Or I might have brokes it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We use that…

Speaker: Brok
Text: I know you do! So I took a few gusts from them Winds of Hel and made it so it ain’t just one-way. Now you can use it to travel to and from. If I didn’t breaks it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then we can take it to Freya.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: There’s an idea, brother!

Speaker: Brok
Text: Might be some kinks to sort out, but you’ll make it.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Just go, brother. Well, you gentlemen certainly know how to get around.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, this isn’t right. But close enough. He did say there were kinks.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We must hurry. The heart…

Speaker: Freya
Text: You have it?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes.
[He touches Atreus’ forehead.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: Back of your hand.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He is still ill.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I can break the fever, but to heal…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: …he must know the truth of what he is.

Speaker: Freya
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is not so simple.

Speaker: Freya
Text: Help me prop him up? Did I tell you that I have a son too? It’s been… forever since I last saw him. At his birth, the runes foretold a needless death. The babe in my arms was so small, so helpless. I knew right then I would do anything to protect him. No matter the sacrifice… Of course everything I did, I did for myself. I let my needs, my fears, come before what he needed… and I couldn’t see his resentment until it was too late. Don’t make the same mistake. Have faith in him. I know the truth isn’t simple… but nothing is when it involves your child.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is a curse. The boy has been cursed.
[Suddenly Atreus wakes up.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Don’t leave without me.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I will not.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m better now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I see that. Is he well enough to travel?

Speaker: Freya
Text: For now.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It won’t happen again. I promise.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You see that it does not.
[He thanks Freya by shaking her hand. THE SICKNESS COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Freya… I will not forget this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Thanks…

Speaker: Freya
Text: Your father did the heavy lifting. You should stay. Recover.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You have done enough.

Speaker: Freya
Text: You know my door is always open to you.
[Kratos look in a window.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s Vanaheim, isn’t it?

Speaker: Freya
Text: Can you figure that out, did you?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, the window looks like Bifröst crystal… and I know that’s not what’s on the other side of the wall. And, well… It makes you sad.

Speaker: Freya
Text: You are wise for one so young. Yes, this is the window to a home I left long ago. But it’s only a view.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The thing that happened to you in Alfheim… you can’t leave Midgard, can you?

Speaker: Freya
Text: A “gift” from my former husband upon our separation.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why would Odin trap you in Midgard?

Speaker: Freya
Text: Petty cruelty would be reason enough for him. But as with all his rash decisions, he’s driven by fear. The Vanir were the greatest threat to the Aesir until our marriage brokered peace. Many of the Vanir now think I betrayed them… the fruits of my sacrifice- to be hated by my own kind. To trap me here is to ensure I can never make it right.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Now then… before Modi so rudely interrupted us, we were just about to explore Týr’s vault.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. To find the Black Rune. Boy, do you know the way from here?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh. I don’t know.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Sure, you do, lad. We need a boat!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I dunno, I guess we need a boat.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Okay then!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah, see? The boat washed ashore. Someone did call the serpent earlier.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Get in. I will pull. You are quiet. Are you not better?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I guess.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I know you overheard my talk with Freya. You think you understand. But you do not. Why do you say nothing?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You said I was cursed. You think I’m weak, because I’m not like you. I know I was never what you wanted. But after all this, I thought… maybe things were different.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You do not know everything, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No. But at least I know the truth now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The truth… The truth. I am a god, boy, from another land far from here. When I came to these shores, I chose to live as a man. But the truth is… I was born a god. And so were you. Boy? Have you nothing to say?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m… Can I… turn into an animal?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Can you turn into an animal? No… no, I do not think so.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m a god. Mother knew? She was a god too?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No, she was mortal, but she knew my true nature.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m a god. Why did you wait so long to tell me?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I had hoped to spare you. Being a god… It can be lifetime of anguish and tragedy. That is the curse.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What sorts of things can I do? Can I fly? Or turn invisible? I don’t feel like a god.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I do not know the reach of your godhood, but over time, we will learn.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You sure I can’t turn into a wolf?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You are welcome to surprise me…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Is this why I hear voices sometimes? You sure you’ve never heard any?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not as you do.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That’s no surprise. Every god is unique.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So… maybe I won’t get strong like father… but I’ll have abilities all my own!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: You already do, laddy! Your faculty for language is extraordinary for one so young. Time alone will tell what else you’ll become capable of.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So… you knew all along.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I did, lad. But I’ve known more than my share of gods.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Me too, apparently. I wonder who else knew I was a god… Freya for sure… Brok and Sindri?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: They do not need to know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Baldur! Does he know? Is that why he’s after us? Do you know him from before!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The day of your mother’s funeral was the first time I ever saw Baldur. That is the truth.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Hey- we don’t have to go right back to Týr’s Vault, do we? I mean… we’re gods! We can do whatever we want, right? What do you really feel like doing right now?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I will show you.
[They go in search of the dead sailors.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Were all those guys part of his crew? That’s a tough crew.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: And all were his responsibility.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s a lot of responsibility.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Does it frighten you?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Uh…?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Responsibility.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh. Uh, no. I don’t think so. I mean, I think it used to. But not us much anymore.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why is that?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, being out here… with you… It makes me feel more grown up.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hmm.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Týr’s Braziers - a symbol of the light that binds all realms together.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why would he use those strange runes, though?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Now that you mentioned it… he wouldn’t. Hmm.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Seriously, how did this one captain lead so many men?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He had their loyalty. So they followed.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And then they all died. It must’ve been a bad leader.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why do you think that?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, he led all of these men to their deaths.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: True. But these men chose to follow.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hmm…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Even good leaders make poor choices. The best take responsibility for them. Remember this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father, were you ever a leader?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I… Many years ago. Yes. I led men in battle.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Were you a good leader?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is… complicated.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Did you-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No more questions, boy. Focus on the task at hand.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes, sir.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: My… my men are… They roam no longer?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s right! We kille- uh… we laid them all the rest.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I see… So even in death, I am a failure.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: But in life, you were honourable. Strong-willed. And you inspired loyalty. These are good qualities. Aren’t they, boy?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah. I couldn’t believe how many men followed you here!

Speaker: Spirit
Text: I… Thank you for your kind words. May your journey have a more pleasant end than mine.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, you were right. He didn’t seem very satisfied. I guess you never really get over losing the ones you care about.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hmnph. Never.
[They board the boat and sail away. Atreus sees the ghost tower again.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There it was again! It’s there and then it’s not. What does it mean?
[They move on.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This is where the tower to Jötunheim should be. Feels… strange, somehow.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: No doubt some arcane magicks were involved. I would be not at all surprised to learn you were sensitive to that.
[Kratos enter Týr’s Temple and walk to the sand bowl.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Here we go again…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Read it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Death itself I swallow / To spring forth life tomorrow.”

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh… I like that one. I wonder if I wrote it…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Is that the answer there?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It says “Earth."

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Mm. Swallows death, brings forth life…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Go.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Jörð… (Earth…]
[A giant lift starts and our heroes ride down.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I wish I’d known I was a god in Alfheim… I wouldn’t have felt so bad about killing so many Elves.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, I’m not sure that’s the lesson…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You’ve done nothing to regret. The Elves forced their affairs upon us…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No, I get it now. We had god things to do, and they were in the way, dragging us into their little problems.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Again, are we just leaving that there…?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I mean, just knowing we’re gods makes me feel so much… stronger.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Maybe you feel a little too good right now. With power comes a big choice, lad. You can either serve yourself or put your godhood in the service of others. Like Týr did.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: People really loved him, huh?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye. A god of war, but one who fought for peace. Had a reputation for being heroic and lawful, using his power and knowledge to stop wars, rather than start them.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So there are good gods…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Once in a moon. It’s been known to happen, yes.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This one mentions places I’ve never even heard of. Seems Týr really liked to travel.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Týr believed the mind, not might, was key to preventing war and chaos. And he also knew visiting other cultures would give him perspective staying in one place could not. While Odin always hoarded knowledge, guarding it jealously, Týr was open and sharing with his learning and his wisdom. For this, mortals adored Tyr, showing their love by bringing him gifts the world over.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So what ever happened to Týr?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Odin came to regard him as a threat to his rule… he suspected Týr of collaborating to aid the Giants instead of helping to steal their secrets for the Aesir. Same thing he accused me of, frankly- though in Týr’s case, I believe he was right.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You think Týr was helping the Giants?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I do. He felt responsible for the suffering visited upon them by Odin. I suspect he had something to do with helping them cover their tracks.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The missing Jötunheim tower!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Correct. Whatever happened to it, I believe it could only have been done with Týr and the Giants working together.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Where is that Black Rune, Head?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Don’t know. I’ve never been in here.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The stone! That has to be it!
[The Black Rune covers itself in protection rings.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Naturally.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Didn’t think it would be that easy?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No… Was kind of hoping though… So what now?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Brother… a trap for the Winds of Hel. But where do you think the Winds are?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The winds of what?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh… we forgot to mention that? When you were sick, we went to Helheim to get your cure.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You did?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Terrible experience, by the by. Your da’ picked up a new trick though… with a little help from Brok.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Brok was there too!?! I… but… We’ll get back to this later.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah… a sgian-dubh from my homeland. Used to have one of my own back in the day. You should take it, boy!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes, boy… take it. We might need to butter bread somewhere on our travels.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: This is why no one likes you.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow. Look at that!

[Kratos finds a vessel of wine from Greece. He uncorks it and inhales the aroma of his home. Then he notices a vase with the image of the slayer of the gods and beasts on it, his past. He, as if by accident, breaks it.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What’d you find?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Enough distraction. Do not forget why we are here.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay…
[He picks up some Egyptian amulet.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That’s from a great desert land very far from here.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Do gods live there?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh my yes… many, many gods.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Good or bad?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not as simple as that, I’m afraid…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What did you see in the vault that set you off?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is not important.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Seemed important to you.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It was a rash impulse. You need not dwell on my failings.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow. That was almost an apology. Well I guess you do like to smash pottery.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ha!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look, I just want to know the truth from now on, okay? I don’t care if it hurts me or not. I want to learn. Just ’cause you hate being a god doesn’t mean I have to. And I thought the saws were scary. Look! It’s the wolf-giants, Sköll and Hati!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That’s right, “the bringers of day and night."

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ragnarök begins when they catch the sun and moon, right? Did Týr know them?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I don’t know. Liked them well enough to cover massive wall in his vault with them though.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Don’t you enjoy it at all? Being a god? Out on an adventure in some amazing place? Maybe mother wanted us to have a little fun. Everything we’ve seen and done… maybe it was her gift. I don’t see another trap for the… uh…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: “Winds of Hel?” Maybe we can get up to one of those balconies for a better look?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You know… for someone so loved, Týr sure was paranoid.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye. Thanks to Odin — with good reason.
[Kratos turning a cog.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The runestone - it’s lowering!
[Suddenly some vines grabs him.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: ARRRGH!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What’s going on?!?!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Trap…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father!
[Vine wraps around Kratos’s neck and erases Freya’s mark.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy… Get out of here!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m fine! How do we get you out?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Pull chains… on the wall.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But… there are three of them! What do I do?!?!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus… focus. You can do this.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Please hurry! I don’t know yet if I can drown.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay… think. Hati’s the silver one. He hunts the moon. Sköll’s gold and he chases the sun. For Ragnarök to happen, they have to eat them. But these are out of order.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Good boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So the moon goes on the left… sun on the right, with Midgard in the middle. But which bar do I pull?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Right! The middle! Left, boy!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Gotta get them in order: Moon, left… sun, right… with Midgard in the middle.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The middle! The right, boy!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Moon on the left, sun on the right, Midgard in the middle.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Left, boy!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We did it!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, I can’t drown. Guess that’s something.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re not stopping! Wait… what’s that big chain fo- Father! Above you!
[A moving platform begins to lift the captive Kratos to a pointy roof.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy! You have to stop at that chain!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: HOW?!?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I… I do not know!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait! I know what to do!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Her knife?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There’s no other way!
[He jammed the mechanism with his mother’s knife.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s not working! That should have worked!
[At the last second, the mechanism stops and Kratos breaks free.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Her knife…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I know… but it saved you.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That was cunning, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The rune’s free! I think we did it.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye — let’s go see what Týr’s got for us.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh, no… Freya’s protection rune — it rubbed off! What should we do?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We keep going.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There it is! We’ve got it!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy. Here.
[He give Atreus a knife.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: On the day you were born, I made two knives, mixing metals from my home and from this land. One for myself, and when you were ready, one for you. Today is that day.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So I’m a man now, like you.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. We are not men. We are more than that. The responsibility is far greater. And you must be better than me. Understand? Say it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I will be better.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The power of this weapon, any weapon, comes from here…
[He touches Atreus’ heart.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: …but only when tempered by this.
[He touches Atreus’ head.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: By the discipline, the self-control of the one who wields it. That is where the true strength of a warrior lies. You must never forget that.
[Atreus nods.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Good then. Come.
[Atreus uses his new knife to break the seal of the rune.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Dreifa. (Scatter.]
[Kratos takes the Black Rune.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Blank.
[He throws the rune to Atreus as if it were a piece of ordinary stone.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait…
[In his hands, the rune begins to glow. The body of Atreus begin to cover with letters, and the rune itself is crumbling.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The rune! Did you see it?!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yes!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Are you certain?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I got it. Trust me.
[Two huge trolls, Grendel of the Ashes and Grendel of the Frost attack them.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Grendel… Aim for the face.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have beaten bigger.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Heh… “Puny troll!"…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Yeeeeah… I’m turned around, which way is the sandbowl back up?
[At the sand bowl.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Jörð… (Earth…]
[They slowly going up.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re so close to the end…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Sit.
[He takes out the vessel of wine from Týr’s workshop.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Lemnian wine. From the island of Lemnos, near the place of my birth.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Lemnos"…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: To a journey’s end.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Really? Smells like rotten eggs. Is it still good?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Possibly.
[Atreus drinks and frowns. Kratos smirks, takes the vessel and finishes the wine.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Aaaah…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Aaaah…
[They sit in silence for a few seconds, while the platform rises to the bridge.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father? Why did you leave your home and come here! Does it have to do with the other gods there? It’s just… you hate the gods so much. But Týr proves that gods can be good. And you’re good. You only killed those deserving, right?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah, but who’s worthy enough to judge?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Quiet, head. We are. We know better.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Huh. Sounding more like your da’ by the moment.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Ready?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ready.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I think I’m going to like being a god…
[THE BLACK RUNE COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We go where we want, we do what we want, and now we’re gonna go see the Giants!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye! Having learned that travel rune to Jötunheim, we can now head back to the gateway on top of the peak, and put that magic chisel to good use.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nobody’s getting in our way this time! Come on!
[At Brok’s workshop.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: Hey, look who’s back up and about. Didn’t I tell you he’d be fine?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What do you want, Dwarf?

Speaker: Brok
Text: I got another lead on my ol’ pal Andvari. Meet me at the Landsuther Mines? There’s sum fancy-dancy loot in it for you.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Another lead? But we already found him… Well… found his hand, anyways.

Speaker: Brok
Text: I’ll explain it at the Mines. These ones is just south of the River Pass. Now you two want somethin’, or you just going to stand there, all gag-scrapped and slack-jawed?
[Kratos buys upgrades and they go to the room between realms.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look, don’t be mad… but I’ve seen those blades of yours before. They were under the house, when I was hiding. Is that why you never let me down there? Where’d they come from?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: They are my burden. From a life that is behind me.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, they’re in my life to, now, and I’d like to hear that story.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Those days are dead. To relive them is… needless.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How can this be needless if it’s the truth?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: One day, you will understand.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’ll take your word for it.
[They teleport to the realm of fire - Niflheim.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow… it’s hot here. But… is that… snow?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Ash. It’s only falls like that for great fires.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The whole realm is a great fire… the source of fire itself, and all the sun and stars, if legend is to be believed.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Should we believe? I mean… we’re here, and we’re not on fire.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not yet.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, you know… I suppose it’s cooled considerably since the dawn of creation, hasn’t it? Niflheim isn’t exactly ice these days either. It’s in the nature of things extremes are tempered by time. Fires burn colder, men grow old and grey… heads are chopped off and attached to belts. Such is life!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Uh… okay, Mimir…
[They find Brok.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You must like the heat, Brok…

Speaker: Brok
Text: Heat’s damned useful in my line o’ work. Even makes space itself more pliable. Take those magic doors you love so much - ’round here they’ll go right to one another, no proddin’ from ol’ Brok. Go up yonder and wake some up, you’ll see - gettin’ around Muspel’s a cinch… Long as you don’t end up cooked.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Look here. Another.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This one’s called “Surtr"… must be a fire giant.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, the first and original.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He makes a flaming sword…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: A weapon of legend.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He fights Thor and Odin. But is that the past or the future?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Mm… that may be a matter of perspective…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So what do you think, Mimir? What does Baldur want with us?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well… let’s look at what we know. Baldur is Odin’s finest tracker, bar none. If he wants you, you have to consider the possibility that Odin wants you. And as for what Odin wants, on this I have some expertise.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What could WE have that Odin doesn’t? He’s like the king of gods!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Of the Aesir, aye, but his reach is not unlimited. And where he cannot reach, he is preoccupied with going. He certainly tortured me enough about it over the years.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh, almost forgot - Brok, this is our new friend Mimir!

Speaker: Brok & Mimir
Text: We’ve met.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh! Why didn’t you say so?

Speaker: Brok & Mimir
Text: He knows why. I know why? YOU know why!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Quiet! No more of this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Know what, I’m sorry brought it up.
[They leave the workshop ]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So, Mimir… seemed like maybe you know Brok and Sindri…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, the “Huldra Brothers"…? Well, who doesn’t? They’re quite famous. Or infamous, depending on your point of view. They crafted Mjölnir, you see - Thor’s Hammer? The Aesir’s greatest murder weapon, the bane of Giant-kind…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: THEY made Thor’s hammer? I didn’t think they liked the Aesir.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, I should say not… but this was long ago, and they were eager to make a name for themselves. Rather overdid it with that one, methinks.
[They walk into workshop from another realm.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hey Brok, we found something interesting.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Didja now? Well colour me interested. Týr woulda been pleased as peaches knowin’ these offerins were bein turnt to armour.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Did you know him? What was he like?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Never you mind, boy. Týr’s dead. Best not to dig up the past.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The dwarf speaks wisely. For once.

Speaker: Brok
Text: What’s got you all bumfuzzled over there! Get goin’!
[They leave.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m gonna tell Sindri I’m a god. I’d like to see the look on his face.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. I may have kept you a secret too long… but now you will keep OUR secret.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Huh. Why should we hide what we are? Secrets are Odin’s way. Shouldn’t we be open, like Týr?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Týr kept secrets too. For good reasons. To protect people. It is wiser to be discreet.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That doesn’t mean you should lie to your friends, or your family…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’m sure Sindri would understand and do the same, lad. Don’t fret. So, lad… excited to finally see the land of the Giants?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah. But also said the journey’s almost over. Oh! What if we get to Jötunheim, and there aren’t any Giants there either?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Makes little difference to us. Fulfilling your mother’s wish is what is important.
[Large cog rolling from Sindri’s workshop. Atreus stops it.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ah! Don’t go anywhere - be with you in two shakes.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father, can I tell him?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Tell me what? Did you put this wheel in your month? Oh god,I’ll vomit. I’m not kidding. I’ll throw upon it…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It is nothing. A family matters.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh, can tell you a thing or two about family matters…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Let me guess… your brother isn’t as talented as you, and his work is junk.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Uh… those things are accurate. Your point?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s all you ever talk about, over and over. Do something about it or shut up already.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: I see…
[The rain clouds begin to assemble…]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah! We’re sick of hearing about little people’s little problems!
[A thunder is heard.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Umm, alright… That hurt a little. Let’s have a look at your gear then.
[They gear up and leave.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why did you speak to the dwarf like that?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Aren’t you sick of hearing about him and his brother?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Of course. But it serves nothing to make an enemy of him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He should know the truth. Even if it hurts.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It was needless and unkind.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Truth is more important than kindness.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Your mother would disagree.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: She wasn’t a god. Why don’t you let me carry her up from here?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why not? We’re almost there. You know I can handle it!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Can you? After the way you spoke of her, I question that.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What, that she wasn’t a god?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She was better than a god and you shall not dishonour her.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Fine. Carry her yourself.
[They go to the mountain, on top of which are the gates to Jötunheim.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir… If you knew all along that we were gods, why come up with that story about Odin trying to follow us to Jötunheim before we get there, or whatever? Isn’t it a lot simpler if they want us dead because we’re gods, and they think were a threat?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I suppose we can’t rule it out. But Odin’s ways are subtle and his purposes are-

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ugh, enough about Odin and his whole stupid family.
[They walk up the stairs to the peak of the mountain. Peals of thunder are getting louder. A piece of rock breaks off and falls right in the path of the heroes.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa! Phht… I suppose that’s Odin’s doing too. Nice try! You and mother always said all gods were evil… but we’re not! Týr wasn’t. Freya neither. The Aesir gods - that’s who’s evil. And you know what - Odin’s right. We are a threat. Cause we know what they are, and we know we can beat them.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, not all of them. Not yet…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Magni did his worst, and he’s dead. They’re no better than us. And they’re gonna be sorry they picked this fight.
[In a room with a deer-headed god, they meet Modi. He is severely mutilated.]

Speaker: Modi
Text: Thor… blamed me… ME… for what you did to Magni. My own father call me a coward…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Looks like he did more than that. Move it or we’ll pick up where he left off.

Speaker: Modi
Text: I’ll kill you-! Aah!! Aah… aah…
[He falls on the ground in pain. Atreus looks at Kratos.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. He is beaten- not worth killing.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He should pay for what he said about mother.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I said no.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But we’re gods. We can do whatever. We. Want.

Speaker: Modi
Text: Hehehehe… that’s what I said to your mother… Right before I gave it to her.
[Atreus stabs him in the neck.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What are you doing?!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This is a much better knife than Mother’s.
[He kicks Modi and he rolls off a platform.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You killed against my wishes. You lost control.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Haven’t you been teaching to me to kill?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have been teaching you to survive. We’re gods, boy… and that makes us a target. From now until the end of days, you are marked. So I teach you to kill, yes… but in defense of yourself. Never us an indulgence.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nobody cared about him anyways. What’s the difference?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There are consequences to killing a god.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why? How do you know?  How do you know!?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Watch your tone, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whatever.
[They continue their journey to the top.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Pff - this used to be a challenge.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Keep your wits about you, boy. If Modi found us, Baldur cannot be far.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Good. I have a few words for him too…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No, you do not. You will leave him to me.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So you can kill him. Cause that’s what we do to our enemies. RIGHT? Cause he’d do the same to us!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I will do only what is necessary.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And I’ll help.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: NO.
[They return to the mine.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh yeah, this room. But we need a new way up.
[They fight some enemies, during which Atreus doesn't heed Kratos' commands and attacks on his own.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Have you forgotten your training?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh, are you talking to me? Thought you didn't like my tone.
[They ride on a elevator.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can’t learn if you won’t teach me.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You do not heed my lessons.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’ve done everything you asked, and all I wanted was the truth. Where did you get your fire blades? (Kratos don’t answer) Why did you hide them? (Kratos don’t answer) You said there are consequences to killing a god. You used the blades to kill one? (Kratos don’t answer) Who else did you kill, before Magni? How many? (Kratos don’t answer) Do you hear me?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I heard you, and these are not subjects for discussion. Do not push me, boy.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Fine. Mimir guess what I know everything I need to know now. I have nothing else to learn.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Uh… congratulations?
[Atreus sees some enemies.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Die!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy!
[After the fight.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What does this say?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It says… “Don’t wake him". Whatever. We’ve killed everything else in this mountain! Who else wants a taste?
[Huge ice troll break the door and hit Kratos.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh! I felt that one brother!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Kráku lið! (Shitty crew!) To think I used to feel bad killing these guys….

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Brothers, be warned- the tunnels I’m seeing in the walls up here show signs of recent Dragon activity-!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We already killed that dragon.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah. Did ya then? Well. How’d that go? Come ON, you two… the silence is getting unnerving.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Don’t worry about it. We’re focusing.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Nearly there now!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Finally…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy, the rune.
[He approaches the body of Mimir…]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well. There’s a sight no man should ever see. Thanks for that.
[Kratos goes to the gate and looks at the rune that seals them.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Carve along that.
[Kratos breaks the seal and open the portal to Jötunheim.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow. Jötunheim. We made it.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Beautiful, isn’t it? Why, I remember once- Brother! Look ou-

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Miss me?
[He pierces Kratos with a piece of rock.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Run, boy! Cross the bridge!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No! I’m a god too! I can do this! Get off him! (shoots Baldur in the face]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Really?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Baldur. Let ’em go. Take me instead. I’ll do whatever you-

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Shut up. All of this time, I thought I needed you! But, you’re just meat! Turns out the boy’s the brains!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: RAAAAAA!
[He punches Baldur and throw him to the gate’s ark.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: NO!!!! You broke the gate! That was our only way to Jötunheim!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Oh, you stupid son of a bitch!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Get out of here, boy!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Yes… by all means, junior, run away. Lat daddy do the all the heavy lifting for you.
[Atreus runs to Baldur, but Kratos stops him.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Let GO!!!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Calm DOWN, boy! You are NOT ready for this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I AM ready!!!
[He’s pulling on his bowstring.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy… I…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Þruma—!!
[Kratos’s exhausted body is pierced by an electric arrow.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: And here I thought my family was fucked up…
[While Kratos is immobilized by electricity, Atreus is trying to attack Baldur again. He sticks his knife into his shoulder.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Aww… your father is right boy. You are far from ready. Now, would you be so kind as to hold this for me? Thank you.
[He takes the knife out of his shoulder and stick it in Atreus’s shoulder, puts it on his shoulder and jumps off the cliff.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: ATREUS!!
[Kratos runs after him and jumps off the cliffs, too. He lands on the back of a flying dragon.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Don’t know when to give up?!?
[They’re starting to fight, but Kratos is getting the upper hand.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: STAY! AWAY! FROM! MY! SON!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Weak! YOU WON’T STOP ME! I WILL break you!
[An epic battle on the dragon’s back takes place. Eventually, Baldur manages to kick Kratos off the dragon. He lands and run to the gates between worlds.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: Who’s activated the bridge? Hey! I asked you a question—

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Too late, it’s locked in. And when the bridge opens, the full weight of Asgard will come crashing down on you. It’s over.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Is it? So be it.
[He trying to use the Bifröst.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: BALDUR!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: NO! Listen to me!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Let me help!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Let go of him now or I will kill him. You know I will.
[Kratos activates the gate.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: What did you do…?
[Atreus, Baldur and Kratos are sucking in Helheim. Kratos manages to punching Baldur in the flight.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: BOY!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m here…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stay still.
[He lifts an ice block and pulls Atreus by the arm.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You will LISTEN to me and not speak a word. I am your father and you, boy, are not yourself. You are too quick to temper. You are rash, insubordinate, and out of control. This will not stand. You will honour your mother and abandon this path you have chosen. It is not too late… This discussion is far from over. We are here because of you, boy. Never forget that.
[RETURN TO THE SUMMIT COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow, it’s cold. This is Hel?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not just Hel… worst place in Hel you could’ve put us.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I see a ship.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Get us there. It only takes us halfway to Týr’s Temple, but at least it gets us far from here. For a thousand mortal lifetimes, the Bridge Keeper kept the living out of this place. But now that you’ve ripped his heart out, here we are. Funny how it all comes around.
[In one of the towers, Atreus sees the ghost of his past as he killed Modi.]

Speaker: Spirit of Atreus
Text: He should pay for what he said about mother.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That… wasn’t me. It was me…

Speaker: Spirit of Atreus
Text: But we’re gods. We can do whatever we want.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Turn away, boy.

Speaker: Spirit of Modi
Text: Hehehehe… that’s what I said… to your mother… right before I gave it to her.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That wasn’t me. I couldn’t have done that.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Do not dwell on those thoughts. Not here. We must keep moving.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah.
[They continue the journey.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head. What was that?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not just the old and sick come to Helheim… so do the criminals. Hel must not draw a distinction between us and those whom these visions are meant to torture.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How do we stop it?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Escape Hel. As soon as possible.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m not gonna let it bother me. Like you said, Mimir - it was just an illusion. That wasn’t me.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. But it is who you have become of late.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look, I know I got us into this. But I’ll get us out… whoever I am.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: *I* will get us out. You will follow orders.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But maybe that’s not who I am.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It had better be. Now let me focus.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait, I think I see Baldur up ahead…
[They’re climbing the wall and listening to the conversation.]

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: No… no, I would never have wanted this!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stay out of sight.

Speaker: Spirit of Freya
Text: Listen…

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: You… had no right.

Speaker: Spirit of Freya
Text: I had every right. I am your mother.

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: You had no RIGHT, Witch!! I can’t taste. I can’t smell. I can’t even feel the temperature of this… this room. Feasting… drinking… women. It’s all gone. Gone!

Speaker: Spirit of Freya
Text: But you will never have to feel pain again. Death has no power over you now. You would rather die?

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: Than never feel again? Yes. YES! I would rather die.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: Take it away, mother. Please… please, please, take it away

Speaker: Spirit of Freya
Text: …I can’t. It doesn’t work like that, Son.

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: Oh please… (crying]

Speaker: Spirit of Freya
Text: Trust me in time you will thank me. You will thank me.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: No… I won’t… won’t. C’mon… c’mon.

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: You ruined my life.

Speaker: Spirit of Freya
Text: Honey, we can figure this out. I promise, trust me, I know how -

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: NO!! No, not if you can’t fix it, Mother.
[He raises his hand to hit Freya.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Come on. Do it. DO IT! Do it. COME ON!
[But… he can’t do it.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Coward!

Speaker: Spirit of Baldur
Text: I never want to see you again. Never.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: What you did to me… WHAT YOU DID TO ME!! (screams and yells]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Freya is his mother. Why did you keep this from us. Head?

Speaker: Baldur
Text: I’m a coward… I’m a… I’m a coward. I’m a worth. worthless coward (continued crying]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Would you believe it slipped m’mind!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I would not.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’m at a loss. I assure you I’ve no reason to keep such a thing a secret.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There’s the boat. We will speak more of this. Soon.

Speaker: Spirit of Zeus
Text: Such chaos. I will have much to do after I kill you.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Who was that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We must hurry.
[They find the ship.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Er… not entirely sure this is seaworthy.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She will do.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Now what?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Give me space to work.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Let me help. What can I do?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You have done enough.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The sails are intact! We’re moving!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Great. Just bear in mind - this boat can only take us part of the way. Týr’s Temple is near the top of a tremendous waterfall which, sadly, we are downstream. That means even if we get there intact, we’d still need to sail UP a waterfall somehow.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The Vanir built the greatest ship that ever was and it can fly.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Skíðblaðnir? Yeh… because it was designed to fly. This was not.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Nevertheless, this is the boat we have. We make do.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Owp! We’re stuck.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: On perhaps the biggest iceberg I’ve ever seen. At least the fire’s making heat. What now? You’re chopping it…?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Give your father room.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So now the sails are loose…?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Just watch.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You cut the sails loose. You’re pulling the sails down? But how they gonna catch the wind? We’re floating! The heat from the fires! We’re actually floating! Aaaaaand we’re stuck again.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not for long. Stay with the boat.
