Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can’t believe it. You just made a huge sky lantern. That did it. We’re loose!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Wait for me there!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: We need to talk, brother. You do realise it’s over, don’t you? Even if we make it back to Midgard, you and Baldur destroyed the only gate to Jötunheim. We are out of options. And that boy up there… he’s in nine kinds of pain. He’s heads turn so far around, he-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus is not your concern.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, he might become everyone’s concern if you don’t do something. You don’t have to be the smartest man in the world to see that.
[Kratos return to the ship.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I can help?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Together now.
[Together, they lift a huge stone bridge and free the ship.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We did it. We’re free. We are going to get out of here.

Speaker: Spirit of Kratos
Text: Face me, father. It is time to end this.

Speaker: Spirit of Zeus
Text: Yes, my son. It is time.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s that voice again. Do you know who that is?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I… do not know.
[They’re fighting advancing enemies trying to contain the ship’s movement.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Almost there. We’re free!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head, how long before we reach the temple?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah, it’s freezing!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: As long as we maintain this speed and those fires don’t go out, we should be there in no time, lad.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Þruma! We’re free! Mimir? How’s the fire staying lit?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Would you believe “magic"?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Or those blades….

Speaker: Spirit of Zeus
Text: It is time, my son. Look around at what you have done.
[Spirit of Zeus appears on the ship. We see the final scene from God of War III - Kratos beats Zeus to death with his bare hands.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Come on. We gotta go,

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You saw…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There’s no time! LOOK!
[They crash into a statue and the ship falls apart.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I have a plan! JUMP!!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That was your plan? You’re both cracked!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We are leaving this realm. NOW.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: As long as we didn’t wreck our way back… What is this place?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: This is Odin’s. I’d recognise his atrocious taste anywhere.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I think this is where Odin brought all his best clues about Jötunheim! Look at that! It’s the missing panel, about Týr. Odin must have stolen it. But why?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He always has his reasons. Might I have a look? Well… this is most unexpected.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why? What does it mean?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I haven’t the foggiest. Isn’t that unexpected?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Look, clearly that’s Týr… travelling, somehow, perhaps magically. But what’s that to do with the Giants, that they should devote a shrine to it? I’m afraid that is none too clear.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What are those runes in the corners?
[He points to omega symbol in the right corner.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not runes. Symbols… from different lands. They mean-

Speaker: Kratos
Text: War.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How do you…?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This one I know too well.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: His eyes. They are jewels. Like yours.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: No doubt signifying the gift of sight the Giants granted us… Give me a closer look. Interesting…
[The panel slightly changes.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Very interesting.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: What is that!?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Secret plans, concealed by Týr so none could access but him… and those few others the Giants trusted. And right under Odin’s nose-- ha-ha! I did promise I’d get you to Jötunheim…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What do you mean, head? You said we were out of options.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Don’t you see, brother? Odin never gave up hope, and neither should we. He knew there was a clue in here, but we’re the ones who found it. But these plans to some chamber Týr kept hidden. I don’t know where it’s leading us or what we’ll find… but it’s a path.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: How do we make this key?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I suggest we ask a dwarf.
[ESCAPE FROM HELHEIM COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That symbol on the temple door… It’s a bunch of runes together. Peace. Unity. Hope, other things too.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Týr own design. He made this door himself.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy… Before… what you… saw…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I didn’t see anything.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You did not see me with someone? An old man?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What old man? Can we go?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes… very well.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Alright, let’s get back to Midgard and see about making that key. Where’s that dwarf?
[Kratos uses the Bridge Between Realms.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now, head-- why did you not tell us Baldur is the son of Freya?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He IS! It’s shocking every time I hear it and yet obviously I know it. But when I think about Baldur and Freya, I…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Yes, lad?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Freya.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: How’s that, brother?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Head, tell me Baldur’s vulnerability.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Baldur is blessed with invulnerability to all threats, physical or magical.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait, what is happening?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He is bewitched not to speak of what he knows.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I am? I AM! That’s it precisely. Ooh… I wonder how long that’s been so-- since she had m’head at her mercy, or back when I figured out Baldur’s weakness.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Yes, lad?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You just said you figured out Baldur’s weakness!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Did I? But Baldur is blessed with invulnerability to all threats, physical or magical.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Enough. This means there is a way. If he troubles us again, we will find it.
[He leaves the room between worlds and approaches Brok, showing him a book from the Týr’s library.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Can you make it?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Is it a weapon? Armour? Or likewise an instrument of war of which I’m a master at shapin’? No? Then forget it. Even if I wanted to make such an insignificant gewgaw, I’m liable to chink my tools working on something so delicate and ladylike.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Then shingle it. Pattern weld the item with skap slag. Keep the layers thin, alternate the overlay.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Okay, smart guy. And where d’ya propose to find a lump of quality skap slag? Last time I saw one, I could still get rigid down south.
[Sindri pulls it out of her bottomless bag.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: Shut your mouth. Is that…? Where did you…?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: I had to get my hands dirty. (gags]

Speaker: Brok
Text: Well, don’t just stand there-- let’s do this!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: What? You? You’re fine with working on something that’s not a weapon?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Ah hell… why not? What? I can grow too…

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh, watch the spine. Keep your wrist loose.

Speaker: Brok
Text: YOU keep your wrist loose. I need more heat here!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Coming up. You going to temper that steel longer?

Speaker: Brok
Text: I don’t need to-- I triple-quenched it with Draugr oil. See?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh, how inventive. And sanitary! You clever little beaver! Never too late to learn a new trick, is it?

Speaker: Brok
Text: No, it’s not!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Here it is!

Speaker: Brok
Text: Nope! Don’t forget this!
[They put their brands together and put it on the ready-made key.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: On quit yer grinning. It’s downright unsettlin’ hrmm.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s just nice to see you together. But… now the rune on your brand looks different.

Speaker: Broke
Text: Yeah, price of uh… reforging something what broke.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I knew it. You two love each other.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Oh, cut it out, princess. You’re gonna get me all weepy.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: I like the new one better, don’t you?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We have work to do.

Speaker: Brok
Text: What’s got you all bumfuzzled over there! Get goin’!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Now we just need to figure out what door this key opens. It has to be somewhere around the temple…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Týr’s rune. This is it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re inside! But… what is this place?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Your guess is as good as mine, little brother.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The tree! We’re underneath the realm travel room! But… why is the floor on the ceiling?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Those realm doors seems to mirror the ones above.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Up there. Týr used the same magic to protect the Black Rune. The clue we seek may be inside.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hunh-- Right next to the Jötunheim door!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Interesting… but can you reach it?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Not from here.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh! What’s behind there?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well! One inner sanctum within another…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Those tapestries… looks like more Giant art… Whatever Týr did for them must have been big.
[There’s two giant stone trolls in the room.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa. Who are they?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy… this is the rune for Jötunheim?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That’s right… and look-- were on the other side of the door.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The upside-down door…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What are you thinking?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stand back.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ooo-kay.
[Kratos literally trying to flip the entire temple upside down.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s moving!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: What’s moving?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: RAAAAA!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Whoa!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Extraordinary. The whole room is built on some kind of axle.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There’s chains on both sides. Without those…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: …we can flip the temple.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: All right!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Do what now?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Uh-oh… things are happening!
[Giant trolls on both sides are pulling chains.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Okay… I don’t think they’re attacking. Want me to read this one?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy-- on the statues.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I see them… it says “Void.”

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Hm… Ominous.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Go on, read.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Before the first after the last / Nothing between, no shadow cast” Auðr… (Void…]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Are you quite sure flipping the temple is the only way to reach the whatever-it-is?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You said there would be a path. The temple can be lipped.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Therefore… we flip the temple. The logic is unassailable… Hm… not sure what happens when we recklessly upend a room that’s rooted to eight other realms. I’m curious, of course… but it’s a leap to imagine it gets us to Jötunheim.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I don’t mind a leap.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well… who knows-perhaps you and Týr are the same kind of mad.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Here, boy. Another one.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It says his name is “Bergelmir”-- I think mother said he was the King of the Giants,

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, that he was. And quite a bit more.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Looks like he had a LOT of kids.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That little brother, is what we call an understatement.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He’s dead… but nobody killed him. Do Giants die from old age?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: They may. Though it’s rare, among the legends.
[At the first chain.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Until gods grow good.”

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Could be quite a wait.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nah-- they’re just waiting for us.
[At the second chain.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: “Leave them in Peace”

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Obviously not referring to us…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Brothers… I know what I promised, but in case this doesn’t work just remember - Týr had good cause to create these obstacles. He’s kept Jötunheim out of Odin’s reach, but the world is hardly at peace.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: No… but it’s got hope. We’re all working together now… we have unity. That’s what the rune on the door to this place was telling us. We’re on Týr’s path.
[Kratos is trying to flip the whole temple upside down again.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Lift with your legs, brother.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He knows.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Just trying to be helpful.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: RAAAAAA!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Bloody outstanding! On the day that brute force is the answer, I’ll be quite happy to be on your side, brother. And we’re not dead-- that’s a plus.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There-- on the left… I think we can climb back up to the Realm Travel Room from there! See that, Mimir? Nobody could do all this alone. All these obstacles… they’re just chances to prove we’re the ones who can beat them. We may argue… me and father, you and Freya, Brok and Sindri… but when we all work together, we DO make a good team… and that’s Týr test. That’s why we’re gonna male it to Jötunheim.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Do you hear that, brother? Lad’s found his equilibrium.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What’s that mean?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He means you speak wisely, Atreus. And that is good to hear.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ha! I guess the Temple was made to be flipped.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look, the tree’s upside down! Or… are we? I’m sure anymore.
[They found a cloud of mist with a mask floating in it.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy, your knife.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Dreifa. (Scatter.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well? What’ve we got?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Some sort of travel stone.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Let me see… Great Auðumabla’s udders-- that’s the Unity Stone!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You know it?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I wasn’t sure it existed! If Týr possessed this, that explains how he could visit all the realms, and other lands, to boot.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He held this. In the panel in Odin’s library.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Yes! That’s it-- I understand now. It shows Týr walking the Realm Between Realms. You know how you must never stray from the path? Well. Týr always followed his own path, if you catch my meaning.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The Realm Between Realms…
[A PATH TO JÖTUNHEIM COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So you’re saying Týr’s shrine was showing him stepping off the branch of the world tree. And you’re thinking, to reach the secret path to Jötunheim, that’s what we need to do?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I am.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, dear. That is what you’re thinking, isn’t it?
[They exit the travel room.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: What’s got you all bumfuzzled over there? Get goin’!
[They enter the door between realms.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: If you’re thinking about hurling us all into the void, I hope you’re quite sure.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wasn’t it your idea? Find our own path, right?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Bollocks…
[Kratos approaching the edge of the cliff.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This is where Týr stepped beyond… and the Unity Stone protected him. Ready?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ready.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well… if this is it, lads, it’s been an honour.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Have faith, Head.
[They jump into purple abyss.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This is incredible!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I… thought… there’d… be… a… bridge…!
[They land into another pathway.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ach… how can I be so nauseous without stomach?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Come on, that was great…! Look… The tower! I knew there was something down here…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Amazing. How do you hide something that exists in all realms? Cast it out of any realm to the space between. Clever old Týr.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Is Jötunheim on the other side?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: But how do we use it?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’d suggest we look inside. But stay alert-- Týr’s little challenges are never as simple as they appear.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have noticed.
[They enter the tower.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well… this is sparse.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The pedestal…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh no! It took the stone!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The tower… It’s absorbing the stone’s energy…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Something’s happening! Is it moving? It’s moving!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It knows what to do. The stone served its purpose. We’re fulfilling Týr’s spell!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What happens now?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: No idea, brother… but after that fall, I’m sure we’re past the worst of it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Smells like Niflheim all of a sudden…
[A lot of monsters are starting to attack from all sides.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oop! No, this is considerably worse. On your right!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And stay down!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ugh - glad that’s over… Now where are we?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh… looks like Alfheim! Þruma! Fire, incoming! Þruma! Watch ’em! Þruma! Fire, incoming! I can’t yet. That was tough… where do you think it’s taking us next?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I do not know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh no… we’re back in Hel?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh dear, here they come!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Enemies ahead.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I got him! Almost ready. Kráku lið! (Shitty crew!) Þruma! Sorry, not ready.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Surely that’s enough of that.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Muspelheim! This won’t be good. Watch ‘em!
[Two trolls named Dauði Munr attacks our heroes.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: They attacking at the same time. That’s fair. Þruma! Not ready. Take that, draugr!
[The heroes wins and exit the room.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look, we’re back in Midgard! There’s the bridge! We did it-- the tower’s back where it belongs!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now Týr’s travel room can take us to Jötunheim.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How did Týr do this?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Odin suspected the Giants secretly possess some remnants of primordial Jötnar creative essence-- the stuff all realms were made of. The Unity stone must have been fashioned from that essence. To trust an outsider with it, even Týr, tells you just how desperate they were.
[BETWEEN THE REALMS COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And look-- now we can finally light all the braziers and see what happens! Another name… Göndul!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Another Valkyrie. That’s no coincidence. But who’d have etched them on Týr’s Braziers? I don’t know what we’ll find when we get to Jötunheim, but we must cover our tracks. Odin’s ravens will tell him of the tower’s restoration, and we mustn’t let our efforts be to his benefit.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Very well.
[Kratos sets the travel room to Jötunheim.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: This is it. Here we go!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Hold on, wait a minute… this isn’t going to work.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: There’s no travel crystal. Týr must have used his own eyes to refract the energy. It was his final failsafe.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But you’ve got eyes like him, Mimir.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’ve got AN eye-- one! Odin plucked out my other eye precisely to keep me from travelling. Sorry, lads. Thought that would work…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What did Odin do with your other eye?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He’d have kept it… in any of a hundred places, I’m afraid.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’ve come so far. There has to be a way.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Look… bit of a long shot, but for years I’d see Sindri, sometimes Brok, lurking around on that mountain when Odin came for his visits. Maybe they know something?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Brok and Sindri!
[They go to the workshop.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hey guys. Question for you-- anyone know where we can find Mimir’s other eye?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Oh…  That’s… I’m sorry. As a matter of fact, Odin asked me to… he wanted me to build a… he showed it to me, you see, and I… declined. Sorry, will you excuse me?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, that was useless.

Speaker: Brok
Text: You know… it was about that same time that Odin came around lookin’ for me to build a statue with some sort of hidden compartment.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ah, it’s all over my hands. Is that corn?

Speaker: Brok
Text: Now that not being a weapons and the Aesir being a bunch of pock-speckled cockers. I too saw fit to decline. But I know he got it built just the same.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What was the statue?

Speaker: Brok
Text: It’s that one of Thor, out there flashin’ his sac to the lake.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The statue that the serpent ate.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Sorry about that. Feeling much better.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How are we supposed to look inside the snake?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Inside?! OH, no…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: We’d better go see what the World Serpent has to say about that. Well, lads, I don’t know what lies ahead, but now would be a good time to make sure your gear is ready for the worst. Anything you need to do, I’d do it now. Just some sage advice…

Speaker: Brok
Text: You two goin’ in or what?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Something else we can do for you?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nah, just… glad you guys worked it out.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ah. Well… I could say the same to you.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Ha!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I guess I was getting a bit full of myself.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Told him what he needed to hear, how’s it sounds to me.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Just the same… I’m sorry for how I spoke to you, Sindri. You forgive me?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Already have. Like you said, it all worked out. Now let us get back to work before I get…
[They return to the room between realms.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m confused. I always heard that Baldur’s mother was Frigg.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, Frigg… well, that’s more of a pet name, you see. It means, “beloved.” Something Odin called Freya after they wed. Out of affection, at first, or so I like to believe. As things turned sour, it became a way to manipulate the truth.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How so?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Odin didn’t want Freya, a Vanir goddess, getting credit for anything in Asgard. So anything worthy she accomplished was attributed to Frigg.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Like being Baldur’s mother.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That’s RIGHT-- Freya was Baldur’s mother all along!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: (sighs]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah, Niflheim. Not sure why anyone would want to come here, but… here we are.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It smells bad. What is that stuff? Weird.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes. A strange material.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Blech… what is this stuff?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This mist is cursed.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Cursed?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Quite right. Safe to breathe for a time, but it’ll kill if we linger. Just one more reason to love Niflheim!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ah, fancy seeing you two here!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m surprised you’re here, Sindri. This mist is pretty gross.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You think I can’t handle a little cursed mist? Well, you’re right! I’m trying to build some armour that will lessen its effects. The materials I need are all right here in Ivaldi’s Workshop, but, they’re blanketed by this nauseating mist, of course.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Wait for it…

Speaker: Sindri
Text: The last known location for such armour is in the Workshop’s centre chamber. The entrance is sealed, but I could craft you an Entry Stone with enough Mist Echoes.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: There it is.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There’s something written here… This whole place shuffles around each time we leave? That’s incredible!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus-- focus. This is a dangerous place.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: That’s Dwarven creativity for you. Impressive and dangerous.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Dark Elf, watch him! Ljósta! Kráku lið! Sorry, not ready. Þruma! Fire, incoming! Not yet. Þruma! Almost ready. Þruma!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Might want to start heading to a mist-free area.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That must be the centre chamber. Wolves! Not yet. Þruma! I’m not ready Behind you! Kráku lið! Draugr! Þruma! Need more time.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah, yes, Seiðr poison. Not a fan.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Quiet, Head!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Watch your right! I’m not ready Father, you’re REALLY hurt! Hang on! C’mon. Up! Tell me when… Þruma!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Ooo. Looks like you found enough echoes. AND you’re not dead! Very impressive. It looks kinda run down…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Sindri, how do you make anything out of mist?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Odd as it sounds, the dwarves who lived here could craft marvels out of the mists of Niflheim. Keep an eye out for more Mist Echoes. I could put them to all sorts of use. Be seeing you…!
[Kratos open the door to Ivaldi’s Workshop.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Alright, we’re in! The mist is thinner up here. That’s nice. Is that the armour? It looks kinda run down… Can you wear it?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. It is too small, and too old. We will bring it back to the dwarf.
[They return to Sindri.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Is that what I think it is?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Useless armour?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Useless?! Oh ye of little faith, this armour was worn by Ivaldi himself! Sure, it’s seen better days… but I can restore it with more Mist Echoes, and it’ll help with the effects of Ivaldi’s Curse.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Unless there is something of value in this Workshop, there is little point in staying here.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: You saw all the chests in the centre chamber, yes? Plus all the goodies tucked away towards the back of the workshop. AND the three Realm Tears, of course. But… might want to be careful with those.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why’s that?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: It’s a literal tear in the fabric of reality itself! You wanna reach your hand through there! Be my guest.
[Kratos buys some upgrades.]

Speaker: Sindri
Text: That should tidy up your knapsack. And for the youngster? Something else for you then? Pssst… how about you, young one?
[They go back to the room between worlds.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hang on… Mimir, you called Brok and Sindri the Huldra Brothers?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But… they’re dwarves, aren’t they?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: And Huldra are sprites of the forest…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, beautiful, seductive sprites of the forest.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So why would you call Brok and Sindri the Huldra Brothers?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh…. well… I now realise this would be a wholly inappropriate story for young and innocent ears.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Tsk. Whatever.
[They come into Brock’s workshop.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: You two goin’ in or what?
[Without paying any attention to him, Kratos enters the portal.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Aw, man… the tower ate the Unity stone, didn’t it? I wanted to fly again…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Yes, that’s a terrible pity.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So… Odin wants to go where he can’t reach…. are you saying he’s trying to get to Jötunheim too?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye, it ranks among his foremost obsessions.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But… that doesn’t make any sense, Mimir.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh? When did I stop making sense?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You’re saying Baldur tracked us down to find the way to Jötunheim… but that was before we knew Jötunheim is where we needed to go! That’s crazy!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Except for one thing… you are headed for Jötunheim. So he was right.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m so confused.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well then clearly you’ve been listening.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: What are you fools doing back here? Come to pilfer my boots and small clothes?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We found your son. He… he was betrayed, too. And we found part of his journal. It sounded like he regretted killing you.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Hmph. Fat lot of good that does me. How’d he go out? He die fighting?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We found four corpses near his. They were decapitated.

Speaker: Spirit
Text: Vandrid always did keep his sword nice and sharp… A lesson he picked up from me. He’s a backstabbing bastard, but… knowin’ he’s in Valhalla sets me at ease. Thanks.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We did a good thing! I’m glad we came back here.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That thief did not deserve the peace you gave him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Maybe so. Still, it feels good to help people. Even the dead ones.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hmm. So much like your mother…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir… what else did the serpent tell you when you spoke? Kinda sounded important.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’m sure it’s nothing. He just said the boy seemed familiar to him.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Me? That’s impossible.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh, I quite agree. Unless… perhaps… he refers to something yet to be? It is said that when Jörmungandr and Thor battle at Ragnarök, their clash so violently shakes the Tree of Life that it splinters, casting the Serpent backward through time, even before his own birth.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That is madness.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, I did say not to concern yourself…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It’s my career! And if you mean to make your career as a counsellor to kings, you can’t very well rule out petty maniacs -- available positions are scarce enough! My first master was a cruel piece of work as well, but I learned through him the enduring power of wit, which served me well with kings and gods alike. I couldn’t have been much older than you when I started -- a faerie king’s errand boy, and unofficial jester. By night, my mates and I had the run of the forest. Goodfellows, they called us-knavish sprites to the last. We’d get up to all manner of mischief, making fools of the local mortals, but as long as our lord was kept amused, we were spared the consequences. Then one day, he was not amused, and I saw fit to move on. Thankfully the ages and roads travelled since then have turned me from that merry wanderer into the paragon of virtue you see before you today.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why’s Odin so desperate to find a way into Jötunheim, anyway?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He’s convinced the Giants hold the key to changing his fate when Ragnarok comes. They are the Aesir’s oldest enemies, after all -- and it’s their army that’s supposed to do him in, in the end. But more than that, he covets their gifts of prophecy. He wants to know what they know, and see what they see. So much suffering could have been avoided if his insatiable curiosity was not so much stronger than his wisdom.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What do you mean?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ah -- remind me to tell you why they call him the Lord of the Hanged…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ready!
[He blows the horn. The World Serpent appears.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Thooooor stuh-tooooo… eeeee-kneeeee smooooo-thooooo thooooor-fah.
[The World Serpent answers something.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Ohhhh.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Is the statue lost to us?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Uhh, he thinks it might still be in his stomach. Um… and he’s open to letting you row into his mouth to look inside.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Ew, really?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: By the by, he’s not wild about it either.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Mmmh…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So… are we really doing this? Letting the serpent… swallow us!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You do not have to come.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well, I’m not gonna MISS this… You… sure this is a good idea?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, brothers… I’ve been to many strange places… but this will be a new one.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Heh… yeah, I’ve never been in a Giant’s belly either. How about you, father?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Never one that was not trying to eat me.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: We really should expect that sort of response at this point.
[They go into the mouth of the World Serpent.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Here we go… Funny… I used to dream about getting eaten.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Dreams are nothing to -

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m not afraid. It just reminded me of a way I used to feel. When I was a child. Let’s find that statue.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Huh. Smell’s not as bad as I thought it’d be. A bit like heather ale fermenting. Rather pleasant, actually.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You’re so weird. Ouch… the water kind of burns in here. That is water, isn’t it?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye… most of it…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: There—the hammer.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m glad Brok and Sindri were able to work out their differences.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now they are twice as irritating.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I think it’s nice to see them trust each other again. Mimir… any idea where Odin hid your eye?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: No. It’s not like I can still see through it.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yep. That’s an eye.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Maybe you should stick that in my head for safe keeping. Gently now, gently… Thank you, brother. You don’t miss depth until it’s gone.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: How’s it feel, Mimir?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well I wouldn’t say I’m feeling whole again, but it’s a right improvement.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The Bifröst is intact?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: It’ll serve.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then we have all we need.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Finally, we’re going to Jötunheim. There’s no stopping us now.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Laddy, have you ever heard the term “tempting fate”..?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Fate is another lie told by the gods…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: … told by the gods, yes, of course. You really are your father’s son, you know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So how do we get back out?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We signal the—
[The World Serpent is starting to shake.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hold on.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: What’s going on?! Well that that was mildly terrifying. Maybe our presence is upsetting Jörmungandr’s belly?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. Something is wrong.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What’s happening to him?!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Nothing good! Glad that’s over.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Is he getting hit? What is that?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We must hurry.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Couldn’t agree more, brother.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hold tight and watch your balance!

Speaker: Mimir
Text: The boat’s shifting! I’m gonna—

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have you!
[The World Serpent spits them out. Kratos lands hard on a snow-covered rock. Jörmungandr losses consciousness and falls near our heroes.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy? BOY!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Pffah—! I’m good… Think I’m getting kinda used to this. What happened to him? Something we did?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. Something else… The dead giant… Why would the serpent leave us here?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look.
[He points to a bird floating in the sky. The bird descends to the ground and turns into Freya.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Freya… We can still trust her… right?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Until we know for certain… keep your distance.

Speaker: Freya
Text: The World Serpent… what’s happened here?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We hoped you would know.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You are too far from home.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I’m looking for my son. The two of you… you helped me see things more clearly.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You do not know where he is then?

Speaker: Freya
Text: No. But the woods and fields speak his name. I know he walks here in Midgard.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: When’d you see him last?

Speaker: Freya
Text: Long ago… before you were even born. Why are you standing so far from me? What’s wrong? Something’s happened…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There!
[Baldur comes out of the icy water.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: I had a feeling hurting the big snake would bring the two of you out in the open. Do you have any idea, any idea at all, what you have cost me?

Speaker: Freya
Text: My boy…

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Mother?

Speaker: Freya
Text: I’m here. Don’t run away.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Oh, I’m not going anywhere, mother.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I know that you’re still angry. I know that how you feel hasn’t changed, but I want you to—

Speaker: Baldur
Text: How I feel? How I feel?! I spent the last one hundred years dreaming of this moment. I’ve rehearsed everything I ever wanted to say to you, every word, to make you understand exactly what you stole from me. But now I realise… I don’t need you to understand anything. I don’t need you at all.

Speaker: Freya
Text: No! Back off, Kratos. This has nothing to do—

Speaker: Kratos
Text: This path you walk… vengeance. You will find no peace. I know.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: You… I’ll deal with you later. But family first.
[He’s going to Freya, but Kratos is pushing him away.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: This again.
[The battle begins.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s over. It’s over, isn’t it? You have to go—please!

Speaker: Freya
Text: No! I can reach him! You have to stop fighting! Rot!
[She’s braiding Baldur and Kratos with vines.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: You and your magic ! I hate you!

Speaker: Freya
Text: Son… please. I said STOP! Rot!
[Baldur dodges the vines and throws a stone at Freya. Kratos is braided with vines. He tries to tear them up but fails.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: You might want to turn away, boy. This won’t be pretty.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I won’t let you hurt him.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No, boy…

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Fine.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: STOP!!! NO!!
[Baldur hit Arteus in the stomach as hard as he can.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No… Atreus… you’re bleeding. Breathe, boy… breathe!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Not… my blood…
[Baldur’s body covers the blue glow. We notice that he had a small knife in his hand - he must have seriously injured Atreus and smeared his blood.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: What is this?  I can feel this… I can feel everything!

Speaker: Freya
Text: NO!!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He’s - vulnerable now?
[He’s going to Kratos and Atreus, but Freya’s tangling him with her vines.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: No! Mother!
[Using her UNBELIEVABLY powerful magic Freya TAKES CONTROL over Thamur’s dead body!]

Speaker: Freya
Text: YOU WILL NOT DO THIS!!!
[She grabbed Kratos and Atreus with Thamur’s enormous hand.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What’s going on?!? Is Freya trying to kill us?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. Do you hear the wind? We are moving.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: That arrow… Baldur punched… the mistletoe…?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: In the quiver’s strap, yes. Mistletoe harmed him?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Freya said it was wicked…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: He’s more than harmed the spell is broken!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: He can be killed?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: I’m certain of it. It’s all coming back now…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: NOW he remembers! She’s controlling that thing??

Speaker: Freya
Text: Stay out of it! I can reason with him.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No, woman! You cannot. He means to kill you!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: You can’t stop me. NO ONE CAN.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Where is he?

Speaker: Freya
Text: I don’t care if he kills me. I WILL protect him. I WILL NOT LET HIM DIE!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: How touching… This will all be over soon.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There!
[The fight continues.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: You will stop this, NOW!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Pain! It’s WONDERFUL! More! More! Show me more! Hahahahaha! Ahh!! I feel… I FEEL… FREEZING!!!

Speaker: Freya
Text: No! Stop hurting my boy!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: The chill… it’s better than I remembered! So. Cold. I love it! Ice, snow, wind… I can feel them!
[Kratos pierces Baldur with his Blades of Chaos and throws him against the wall.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: You. Will. STOP!
[Kratos uses his inhuman strength and stops Thamur’s hand. He lifts it up, exposing the crystal on the ring.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy! The crystal!
[Atreus shoots an electric arrow. A powerful explosion throws Kratos back into a small crack in the rock.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus? Atreus!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m up here! I’m okay!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: And I’m doing WONDERFUL! Why I’ve never felt so alive!

Speaker: Freya
Text: Stop this! Þrifa! (Seize!]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Yes, YES!!

Speaker: Freya
Text: Þrifa! (Seize!]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: More! More! More! Show me more! Pain! It’s WONDERFUL! Hahahahaha! More! I never know how much FUN this could be! Hahahahaha! More! More! More! Show me more!

[Kratos throws an axe at him, cutting his shoulder joint. The axe returns to Kratos and he runs to finish off Baldur. Meanwhile, Freya’s giving Thamur a new order. He takes out a piece of the handle from which he died and attacks Kratos.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: Nnngghhh…. NO!!!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: MOTHER!!! I’LL KILL YOU!!!
[He begins to climb the handle. Kratos follows him.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus!
[Atreus jumps to him.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: Stay away from my son! You don’t have to do this!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: There!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Stop him!
[Atreus shoots Baldur with an arrow. Kratos run to him and brutal fist fight begin.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: Please… there has been enough pain.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Shut UP, MOTHER!

Speaker: Freya
Text: No!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: (maniacal laughter]
[Kratos, holding Baldur in his bear grip, is jumping off the handle. Atreus jumps after him while continuing to stuff him with his arrows.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: NOO!!
[They’re landing. Baldur breaks out and starts choking Kratos.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Get… offa him!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Before you die, I want to thank you. Both of you. You’ve done what even the Allfather himself could not. I’ve never felt more alive! Ironic, isn’t it?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: GRYYAHH!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: What?! NO! WHY WON’T YOU DIE!
[Third fight begins.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: NO, Kratos! PLEASE. I need you to stop! Atreus—child! Help me stop them! PLEASE!

Speaker: Baldur
Text: YOU WON’T STOP ME!

Speaker: Freya
Text: It doesn’t have to end this way! I couldn’t let you die! You HAVE to understand!

[Kratos and Atreus, together as father and son, start beating up Baldur. Then Kratos shows Baldur what he did to Zeus at the end of God of War III. Freya doesn’t like it very much. She orders Thamur to blow on them.]

Speaker: Freya
Text: Frjósta! (FREEZE!]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look! I have an idea! Mooooog-taaaaaaay-oooooom!
[The World Serpent appears and grabbed Thamur with his monstrous mouth. By the way, from Tamir’s point of view, the World Serpent looks like an ordinary python or something.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy? Well done boy!
[He grabs Baldur and start chocking him.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Come on… do it.

Speaker: Freya
Text: Stop… please.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He’s beaten, father… not a threat.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: You will not come for us again. You will not touch her.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I don’t need your protection.
[Kratos is letting Baldur go.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: You can’t help yourself, can you mother? No matter what I do or say, you won’t stop interfering in my life.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I was just trying to protect you. I was… I’ve made mistakes. I know, but you’re free now. You have what you want. Try to find forgiveness, and we can build something new.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: No. No. We can’t. Because I will never forgive you. You still need to pay for the lifetime that you stole from me.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I have paid… I have paid. But if that alone will make you whole… if seeing me dead will make things right… I won’t stop you.

Speaker: Baldur
Text: I know.
[He chocks her.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What? No! Father…

Speaker: Freya
Text: I love you…
[Kratos grabs him.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Why… why do you even care! You… You could have… walked away.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: The cycle ends here. We must be better than this.
[He snaps his neck.]

Speaker: Baldur
Text: Snow…

Speaker: Freya
Text: No, no, no, no, no, no, no… My boy… my dear, sweet, boy…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Freya… He chose this.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I will rain down every agony, every violation imaginable, upon you. I will parade your cold body from every corner of every realm, and feed your soul to the vilest filth in Hel. That is my promise.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: He saved your life!

Speaker: Freya
Text: He robbed me of everything! Everything! You are just an animal… passing on your cruelty and rage. You will never change.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then you do not know me.

Speaker: Freya
Text: I know enough. Does he?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy, listen close: I am from a land called Sparta. I made a deal with a god that cost me my soul. I killed many who were deserving… and many who were not. I killed my father.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. We will be the gods we choose to be, not those who have been. Who I was is not who you will be. We must be better.
[Freya, with her dead son in her arms, looks at them and leaves.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well… guess we’re the bad guys now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: In her eyes, yes. But she could never make that choice. We should finish this journey while I still have strength.
[JÖTUNHEIM IN REACH COMPLETED.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I don’t understand… I know saving her was the right thing, but she seemed all evil at the end.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not evil. You killed her son, lad. Her son. The death of a child is not something a parent gets over easily.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But he was gonna kill her!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She would have died to see him live. Only a parent can understand.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So you’d let me kill you?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: If it meant you would live… yes.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Look, there was no easy choice, for anybody, brother. But I think we can all agree you did the right thing. The world’s a better place with Freya in it. Just, give her time, lads. She’ll come around.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Back to Tyr’s temple then. One last time.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye… Jötunheim awaits.
[They get to their boat.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why did Baldur say we cost him?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Odin must have convinced him that following you to Jötunheim would bring his cure. Lies, I’m sure.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Why did Mistletoe break the spell?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Vanir magic is powerful, but its rules are slippery and elusive. I’m sure it makes sense if you’re a witch. Oh, but it’s all so bloody tragic… Baldur was the greatest gift Odin granted Freya: the one thing she treasured from their marriage. She only hoped to spare him pain, and spare herself loss--but such impulses can lead good parents to make terribly stupid decisions.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mimir, you never told me what happened with the stonemason’s son.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Hrimthur, son of Thamur? After completing his father’s master work, the Great Wall of Jötunheim, he thought of nothing but making the Aesir pay for their crimes against the Giants. Once he longed to fight Thor, but tragedy had brought wisdom to Hrimthur— and cunning. He observed that Asgard’s walls were half-built and shoddy, for no Aesir god could be bothered with such tiresome labour. So Hrimthur adopted the guise of an ordinary man, and made the Aesir an offer he would build them majestic new walls, and if he couldn’t build them within two turns of the season, they would owe him nothing for his labours. And if he succeeded, he asked only for an audience with the goddess Freya. Odin agreed, knowing the task was impossible, but intrigued by this stranger. Hrimthur made short work of it, of course he had the benefit of his father’s training, and the aid of a magical stallion for fetching stones. Odin was not happy to find himself on the losing end of the wager, but he seemed to uphold his end of the bargain. Freya was sent to meet the mason, and to her surprise, he wanted only to whisper something in her ear. That being done, he made his way out of Asgard… and when he found Thor waiting him at the gates of Midgard, he knew he had been double-crossed. But he didn’t care, because his plan was complete.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It was? What did he say to Freya?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Only could say for certain, but I’ve had many moons to work it out. Hrimthur knew that Freya loathed the Aesir, despite her marriage to Odin, and I believe he gave her the secret to Asgard’s defences. Some weakness he may have built in structural or magical, which I expect will be exploited come Ragnarök when Surtr arrives to burn Asgard to ash. If not sooner.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Here we go! I can’t believe we’re gonna see the Giants.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Well, if things work according to plan…  Go ahead and lock in Jötunheim and we’ll be on our way. Probably.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy. The head… get ready

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh, right. Got him. Let’s hope this doesn’t cause you to explode or anything.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh. Hadn’t considered that. Maybe we should talk about this a bit more.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Nah. I’m sure you’ll be fine. Ready!
[He reflects the ray of light with Mimir’s head.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oop— that’s unpleasant!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Now, boy!
[Atreus opens the door with reflected light.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We must be close.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Well… what are we waiting for? You think it’s far!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We will see.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: A word, please, before we continue… Listen… the last thing you two need up there’s a decomposing head ruining the moment. Why don’t I wait for you here? This is between you and the boy.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: True. But if someone were to find you—
[Suddenly Brok and Sindri arrears.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: By Lady Sif’s soft, perfect sloshers! You done did it!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Sorry. We had to see this.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Oh-no, no, no. Fine, damn it, FINE.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Watch the head ’til we return.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: I can do this. No… No, I can’t.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Okay?
Action: (with a bit of lust in his voice)

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Ready?
[Atreus nods.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Boy, do I have plans for you.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Do hurry back! Please?!

Speaker: Brok
Text: Don’t flatter yourself, goat-boy.
[Kratos and Atreus climb the stairs to the top of a huge mountain. Everything around is filled with soft golden light.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look… we’re on the Giant’s Fingers. I can see the highest peak ahead-right over there. We did it.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: We did.
[Kratos approaches the edge of the cliff, removes the handcuffs and untie the bandages, exposing burns from the Blades of Chaos.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What are you doing?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I have nothing more to hide.
[The mountain wind takes the bandages away. Kratos stands still for a minute.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Can we go? We’re so close!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy… Carry her.
[Atreus nods and takes the bag.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hm.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Boy?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s nothing… I just thought I’d hear voices by now.
[They go into a huge cave. There are various statues of stone everywhere.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hello? Anybody here!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: What is this place?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: They must have all come through here when they left Midgard. What was left of them.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Why carve all these faces?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What if this is all of the Giants that got out of Midgard alive? Not really many at all… Odin and Thor… ruining everything for everybody…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Where are they now?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: The Giants came back home so they could survive. But I’m not sure they did. Hunh… who’s the “guardian"…? I should feel them… but I don’t. This place is dead. What happened to them? Why’d Mom send us here?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: One question is answered and two more take its place…
[Atreus touche a wall in the cave.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wait! Father… something’s happening…
[Plaster falls from the walls, revealing many beautiful ornaments.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: It’s your axe… It’s mother… she’s arguing with a bunch of Giants. She… knew Giants? That’s us… the first time we met the World Serpent. But how…? And our fight with Baldur… But that just happened. Wait— they knew everything that was going to happen. The dragon in the mountain, the Stone Mason… All these drawings… this is our story.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No… This is your story.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But… what does it all mean?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That I was not the only parent with secrets…

Speaker: Atreus
Text: You didn’t know… She was a Giant… I’m a Giant. Why didn’t she tell us?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: She sent us here knowing we would find this.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But why not just tell us the truth?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Your mother would have had good reasons. Baldur was never sent to find me. He was tracking her all along… not knowing she was only ashes.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: If she had a plan for us… I trust it. Whatever it is. Besides… she hasn’t been wrong yet. Come on, we’re so close to the end now.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Yes… Yes, we are.

[He looks at the ornament, which depicts the future - Kratos lies on Atreus’ knees. Something comes out of their mouths - the soul? Or maybe a huge monster stuck his tentacles in their mouth? Who knows? The climb up to finally scatter the ashes.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Look… it’s mother’s. She was here. She saw every step we took before we took it. Like she was always with us… watching over us… leading us home. Let’s finish it. Father?
[They’re going up to a small area. From the height of the mountain they can see many corpses of Giants left by Thor and Odin. Atreus pulls out a bag of ashes.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Father?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: No. We do it together, son.
[They scatter the ashes in silence.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Goodbye, Faye.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I love you, mom. The giants… They really are all gone. There’s nothing for us here…

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Come.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So… I get that mother was a Giant. Which makes me part Giant and part God.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: And part mortal.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Right. I guess there’s just one thing I don’t understand… Right. I guess there’s just one thing I don’t understand… My name on the wall— The Giants called me “Loki”?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: That was the name your mother wanted for you when you were born. She must have called you that to her people.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But why?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: A question for another day. Let us go home.
[MOTHER’S ASHES COMPLETED.]
[They’re coming down the mountain. The credits rolls on the right.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Guess it all makes sense now. Why she’d want to end up here. Be with her kind. But… did she know it was going to be like this here? Is this what she wanted us to see? Did she want us to tell people, or to keep it a secret?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I… do not know.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: So what should we do?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: I trust you to decide that.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Oh! So… Why’d you want to name me Atreus? I know it can’t be for a God.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Hah. No. He was a soldier. A Spartan.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: A great warrior?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: All Spartans are great warriors. We train from birth. Our lives were discipline, duty, battle, and death. Life was grim, and we greeted it grimly.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: But Atreus of Sparta was unlike the rest of us. He wore a smile even in the worst of times. He was… happy. He inspired us to hope… that though we were machines of war, yet there was humanity in us. Goodness. When the day came for him to lay down his life in battle, his sacrifice saved countless others, and turned the tide in our favour. I carried him home on his shield, and buried him with all the honours of Spartan custom. His memory was a comfort in dark times.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Wow. You actually told a good story. Mimir missed it! I understand if you want to go home… but I bet there are still some corrupted Valkyries out there that could be set free. Some other help people need. Maybe helping people was part of why Mom sent us out here too. I mean… what would Atreus of Sparta do?

Speaker: Kratos
Text: And what would Loki do?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Hunh… that’s a weird name. I’m glad we went with yours.
[They go downstairs to the Room Between Realms.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Lads! Am I glad to see you. I believe I’ve reached my limit for Dwarven charm.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What happened, Mimir?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: They took an uncomfortable number of measurements, and then proceeded to bicker about the weather.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Where do you want us to take you?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: How about the warm confines of anywhere-bloody-else? Before we return to Midgard. I should warn you… more time has passed than you likely realise. And the snowfall that began when you slew Baldur… it’s become something else— the stuff of omens.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Omens? For the coming of winter?

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Not just any winter, but a great winter to span three summers— and when it’s done, Ragnarök begins.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Ragnarök. From snow.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Aye. Snow, lots more snow, and then the end of the bloody world, in that approximate order.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Another prophecy…

Speaker: Mimir
Text: No brother… Prophecy doesn’t expect this for a hundred more winters at least. You’ve changed something. Prophecy didn’t count on you.
[They enter Brok’s workshop.]

Speaker: Brok
Text: I’m telling you, it’s Fimbulwinter. I can feel it in my scrote— this is the big one!

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Stop saying that. Oh, you’re making me very nervous. It was bound to snow sooner or later.

Speaker: Brok
Text: That ain’t just snow, and you know it! It’s the end times.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: How dare you make me the voice of reason!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Guys?

Speaker: Sindri
Text: Just discussing the weather. Bit of a cold snap lately.

Speaker: Brok
Text: What he means is, Fimbulwinter’s upon us, boys! The winter to end all winters! I can feel it in my scrote!

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah, we… We heard.

Speaker: Sindri
Text: So, if you’re heading home… try to keep moving, and also, to not die.

Speaker: Brok
Text: Or if you’re not heading home… same advice.
[Having completed all labours and defeating all the Valkyries, tired heroes return home.]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: We’re finally home… feels like a lifetime ago.

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Bit drafty maybe, but it’s a right improvement over having tree back in your tadger.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Time to rest.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: I’m going to sleep through winter!
[Kratos drops his axe on the floor and lies down on the bed.]

Speaker: Mimir
Text: Okay… this’ll do.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Sleep.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Way ahead of you.
[Kratos wakes up because of lightning strikes destroying his house…]

Speaker: Atreus
Text: What was that?!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Your bow…!
[He grabs his axe and goes out in anger. There he meets a bearded man with a hammer.]

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Who are you?!

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Atreus, are you ready?

Speaker: Atreus
Text: Yeah, but… I had the weirdest dream. Fimbulwinter was ending. And Thor came to us, here at the house.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: It was only a dream.

Speaker: Atreus
Text: But it felt different. It felt real… it felt like the future.

Speaker: Kratos
Text: Then we will worry about it tomorrow. Today, there are still things we can do. Come.
